Another great view in the Cape Town area. Hout bay is another one of the beautiful views just a few minutes away from Cape Town. Worth a visit and a stop. Will definately visit again.

SPECTACULAR HOUT BAY, CAPE TOWN. Yet another stunning beach, with fantastic mountains in the background. This coastal drive to the Cape of Good Hope is a must see as so many beauty spots along the way.

Pretty and pleasant. The republic of hout bay as they refer to themseves is a great place to visit for lunch and a walk in the fresh air. It can also be done in conjunction with chapmans peak drive. There are a few take aways as well as a restaurant. I recommend the fish and chips however. Nice and fresh as the fishing boats are based in hout bay. There are also a few shops for curios and jewellery etc.Not the cheapest but no more than at the V & A. It is also a nice idea to walk down the pier and look at the fishing boats as well as the lovely view. There is a guy who feeds the seals and for a minimal amount will let you take photos with the seals. These are not captive seals they are wild so it does make for a lovely photo. A great place to visit
A visit worth making. This was another beautiful sight. Though the weather was rather cool, being out at the Bay was just so wonderful.

Worth the stop. It deserves the visit. It's on the blue line Hop on Hop off. You can plan the visit at lunch time to enjoy a sea food meal (But rather expensive and touristic price ; almost double price cape town). the views and stroll along the sea is worth it. You will see some seals around.
Another gem in Cape Town. A must do during Cape Town. Driving to/from Chapman's Peak offers Stunning views of the ocean. cannot miss this gem.
Always love Cape Town. One of the most scenic places in South africa, take the beautiful drive along chapmans peak and visit the market in the harbour.

One of my favourite places in Cape Town!. I loved my day at Hout Bay! I love seals and Seal Island (yes, that is an actual place!) is not far from here. So we got fresh fish and chips at Mariner's Wharf which was great. Later, I heard there were also better local places to get amazing food. Then, we went to Seal Island. It's an amazing place with a beautiful view, definitely visit this gem!

So many visitors it is simply amazing. Hout Bay is so alive and interesting.The beach,the fishing boats,the seals,so much to see and do.The best seafood so reasonably priced.Would go there over and over again!
Love it. What I love about this place is close to the sea. I love swiming but I can't, I love the smell of the water. when I'm in that area I just really don't want to go especially in summer
Another Beautiful Bay. A must see when in Cape Town and going on a peninsula tour. Like most of the areas other natural attractions, Hout's Bay is simply beautiful (and windy).

Great tourist attractions. It very much depends what you are going to Hout Bay for as to if you will appreciate it. In terms of scenic beauty and tourist attractions it is great. The stunning Chapman's Peak Drive (when its open), Seal Island, the dramatic Sentinel Mountain and the Weekend Markets are well worth a visit. The beach however is nothing to rave about and you would be better off going to Landudno or Noordhoek if you in this part of the coastline.

reat for day trips!. I would say no to actually living in HB. People are very special and think they own HB and the woman have their manicured nails and little black books! but it is great to go on day trips and get to see the whales and pods of dolphins swimming so close to the bay.

Slightly over-rated. We went to Hout Bay solely for the Seal Colony visit as part of our Cape Point package. Though the place is lovely and the boat ride to the seal colony is quite mesmerizing with the lovely scenery of mountains and water, but the seal colony is quite over-rated. You will find thousands of black seals on a big rock but it is nothing spectacular or wowing (especially since you can find huge game in South Africa and even stuff like Dolphins / Whales etc. in the bay). Given it is very cheap, you should definitely do it, but do not expect that you will be blown away by the experience. There is a local market just next to the boat ticket place where you can get good souvenirs for cheap prices (Negotiate a lot, those people often reduce prices to even 30-40% of what they originally say).The boats are at 20 minutes interval each as there are 3 boat companies each of which has a boat ride at interval of hour. So if you arrive in between, you might have to wait 10-15 minutes.

Scenic delight. Visiting Hout Bay is a must when going to Cape Town. It's a very easy drive and the scenery is just as the pic shows in the little advertisement. The township has some lovely shops and eateries. Meander through the streets and enjoy.
Calamari and chips... Perfect place to be of you are out on a Sunday drive and stop off for lunch. Try out the Fishermans wharf restaurant right out on the docs. Fresh fish and good times assured.

Family weekend. Hout Bay is an excellent place to spend Saturday morning at the Biscuit Mill. It is a food lovers dream with its many different nationalities of eating delights. Its definitely a must visit place. You will need to allow the entire morning to do justice to your visit. Enjoy the food and music.

Sunday Drives!. Best done on a Sunday with a stop for lunch at Fishermans wharf at the village! I go back every year just for the lovely fish, Calamari and Chips! The Drive on Chapman's Peak is absolutely breathtaking!

Wouldn't stop here. Only saw this area from the red tour bus however first impressions seem that the area is run down greatly and needs a make over. Only looked to be a couple of options for eateries.

Magnificent Hout Bay. We've been to Hout Bay many times in my life. If we visit Cape Town it is just one place we never left out. I always used to buy my children and family gifts from the Mariners Warft. Nothing more exciting than a "fresh live oyster to open up by yourself to find its treasure " a breathtaking pearl inside". I remember finding twin black pearls in mine twice. Not to mention the other gifts at the Warft, shell' s , lots to choose from. I love it to just look around, you can't help to stay in the shop a while. Magic' that's the word for it. Then when you go out side don't forget to order freshly baked "geelstert or Snoek" they bake this daily catch for you to absolute perfection. Sit down have your fish meal and enjoy it while looking out over Hout Bay Harbor. There are many things to keep you busy for a couple of days. Bird Park full of beautifull birds. Site seeing. Shopping, going on daily tour s. On the ocean. I would go to Hout Bay once a week if I could afford it.

Great Photography opportunities. This is such a pretty beach and cove and fantastic for photography opportunities. Dont forget to stop at the top of the peak on the way out to take this fantastic photograph as shown on TA.

Fabulous!. We took the blue city tours bus and one of their stops was in Houtbay. So so beautiful, the beach and the mountains. There is the Mariners Wharf restaurant where they serve really good food especially seafood. You can also sea fishing boats come in to the harbour there and watch them unload their catch.
some tourist attraction in Capetown marine drive. on the way to cape of good hope u can enjoy Hout bay. not bad to pass time. entire Capetown is a bay and worthy to visit

Regular Harbor with Restaurants and shops. We passed through Hout Bay during our Cape Town sightseeing tour. There was nothing interesting that would draw our attention. Regular restaurants-most of them selling fish - and shops. It looked too much touristic.

Hout Bay offers variety. Hout Bay offers variety:A fun market with gourmet food, live entertainment and excellent buys; a scenic drive along Chapman's Peak; quaint restaurants; good hotels; the World of Birds; several hiking routes; a child friendly beach (weather dependant).Ideal for those who want to enjoy the great outdoors and indoors
My Beautiful Cape Town. Not really a must see! But there is a mountain pass which is very beautiful but it is not always open during the rainy season as there are rock falls.
Stunning Views!. Gorgeous Views! We ate lunch somewhere there, but I can't remember the name. Make sure to bring your camera!

Sea Lions at Hout Bay. We took a boat from harbour to see the sea lions. Kids loved it. Sea lions are on a large rock "island" at the mouth of the Hout Bay peninsula. The ride is maybe 15 minutes there and the boat stays at the rock for another 10 minutes and then returns. Very worthwhile..
Scenic. Scenic view of the bay and the mountains, and delicious sea food to eat. Have some nice pictures for your FB account as well :)

Lovely place. Stayed for three days, using as a base to tour Western Cape. Apart from road maintenance inconveniences, we loved the area and all the places we could reach and visit; good variety of restaurants locally, and a good place to chill

Hidden Gem. The drive along Chapman's Peak that brings you to Hout Bay is an engineering wonder that is worth it every single time you do it. Hout Bay has a rustic, peaceful feel about it that is pretty unique in the Cape Peninsula

Hout Bay, a lovely little beach town. I stayed in Hout Bay with friends and found the little beach town to be charming. There are little shops and restaurants and a few beachfront cafes. The beach is wide and flat, but the water is very cold.

Pretty damn special barring road closure. Hout Bay has everything. Not to big or to small, good quality restaurants and friendly people. Stupid road closure is not great at moment. Don't scratch beneath the surface at night.

seals@ Hout bay. Great place to see seals on a tour or in the bay trained by a local he calls the seal he jumps on the harbour wall and throws fish to him as you stroke him and get your pictures done winner all round

If I could move, I'd settle here.. Hout Bay is a valley on the Atlantic seaboard about 20 K from downtown Cape Town. It's an area populated by both beach bungaloes and larger homes. This area developed as a result of the need for timber to repair ships who have anchored in Table Bay before continuing on to the spice islands to the East and the Orient. The location is beautiful and sheltered. The beach is one of the nicest in the area.

Paradise - spoilt by us.. Wonderful place to visit, but when you dig a little deeper & look at the sea from on high on a clear day you can see the SEWAGE outfall in the bay - not far from where people go diving with seals. Whales & dolphins also visit the bay & have to suffer our constant untreated effluent discharges.

Great sea expedition. Hout Bay is like going back in time to a traditional fishing village.It has a very relaxed,laid back atmosphere,where you see seals sunning themselves on the harbor rocks.If you want to go out on the boats to seal island then its better to go earlier in the day,as usually towards the afternoons the sea is rough and the boats don't go out.It is a wonderful expedition to go out to seal island and be so close to such a big colony of seals,as well as see the views from the boat.We normally take the city sightseeing bus,which stops at hout bay as well.

One beautiful bay. Driving down from Chapman's Peak where you took amazing photos of Hout Bay, down to the the Hout Bay Hotel for an excellent seafood lunch, with the terrace over looking Hout Bay. Then visit the harbour, walk on the beach.

White sands and beautiful water. Hout Bay is an institution that has to be experienced. On the drive past Mount Nelson and through the mountainside vegetation, you see the change of scene as you cross to the other side of the mountain.Hout Bay jokingly declares its own republic status and has its own "passport". But you obviously don't need one to visit - its just a novelty. The beach and harbour is easy to find and a pleasant stroll to enjoy. Make sure to visit the seafood market and restaurant at Mariners wharf.

Hour Bay views. View, view, view. One of the most beautiful places in South Africa.
And a definate place to visit for brilliant food is Mariners Wharf. Harbor with fishing boats makes beautiful photographs.

Stunning beaches. If you visit Cape Town Hout Bay is a 'must see'. The view from the beach is beautiful. The beach is lovely to go for walks. There are also a variety of restaurants in the area: close to the beach and in the town itself.

Beautiful bay . Hout bay is the gem of the Cape- near enough to get to camps bay, clinton, waterfront etc yet far away enough to be out of the stream - it is gorgeous with much to do ...or nothing at all.

Watch your back !. Attractive community by the sea with spectacular views. Boat trips out to the seals are worthwhile. Selection of shops and resturants by the marina. Some hassle from locals which can be unpleasant.
Fish and chips by the sea. Another must-do on your bucket list for Cape Town. Go order fish and chips take-aways at the harbour and enjoy life passing by in this beautiful part of the peninsula

Seal inland - Hout Bay. This is a very nice experience for the boat trip on the winter day go to the seal inland.
To check the gift shop is another good things to do as well.
Fresh from the ocean. There is an excellent seafood restaurant right on the beach which serves amazing fish and chips, shell fish and snoek. A must visit!

Salty, fishy treats. A drive along the Atlantic ocean ,brings you to Hout Bay, where a feast awaits at Fish on the rocks. Spend an afternoon browsing the markets for crafts or a walk on the long stretch of beach.
Best day out. When I'm in Cape town I always go there for good food and a enjoyable day out. This is like some of the towns in Eastern Cape. So much to see and do that one day is to short to see all.

BEAUTIFUL HOUT BAY AND THE REALLY FRESH FISH. Hout Bay is just one of those places you have to see when you're in the Cape. I remember the fresh fish shop...I remember it because the fish really ARE fresh...and I knew that because there wasn't that awful fishy smell. I then walked down on to the beach and dared to stood where the waves could just reach my feet. It's so peaceful and aesthetically pleasing, you can't help but just soak it in.

The Other Side of Table Mountain and heading South. Part of the experience of Hout Bay is driving there - the are a number of ways but two add considerably to the experience. Firstly if you drive up from Cape Town and around the back of Table Mountain you drive past Camps Bay and the Twelve Apostles and then closer to Hout Bay you pass the picturesque town of Llandudno. (Currently there are road works along the way but these do not spoil your enjoyment). The other route is to drive from Noordhoek to Hout Bay via Chapmans Peak - on a nice day this is a spectacular drive (although you will pay a road toll for the experience). Once you drive into Hout Bay head for the Harbour, Fishermans Wharf and the beach on the bay. The Harbour is a quaint place to visit and we were lucky enough to see two Sea Lions playing in the Harbour. The stroll along the beach is also pleasant on a nice day. Fishermans Wharf has some nice shops to browse and look for small gifts for friends and family and some nice restaurants where you can eat. We ate at the upstairs Fisherman's Wharf, sat outside listening to some buskers playing jazz - an altogether delightful way to spend a Sunday afternoon.It is well worth the visit to see the other side of the coast.
Too Beautiful to Miss!. The views of Hout Bay are spectacular! The sun shines on the glistening blue water & your heart just stops! It is definitely worth a drive by!
Fish & Chips. Best fish & chips served at hout bay. You might be lucky to play with the seals on the dockyard for a small tip.

Make sure you visit the seals. A pretty harbour, good beach and a stunning view back from Chapmans Peak Drive. If you visit make sure you take the boat trip to see the Cape fur seals at nearby Duiker Island. Along the quayside you will find many stalls selling local crafts and souvenirs.

Beach and scenery. This is a great beach for walking, but too cold for swimming in May. Many eateries are open, few are crowded. There were areas of lots of dogs, but easily avoided and the dogs scared off easily with the threat of throwing something towards them.

SNOOKIES. SNOOKIES restaurant and take-away is where we had lunch daily. Their freshly fried snoek fish and chips is simply irresistible. They also serve other combos such as, snoek, calamari and chips, etc. Whenever we holiday in Cape Town, we automatically turn towards Hout Bay and visit Snookies. There are other restaurants and take-aways in the area but his one is my favourite. This business started in the early 1950's, where fish and chips were prepared and sold from a mobile vehicle. They catered for the people that worked in and around Hout Bay. Today the business has grown to cater for tourists as well. The restaurant is simple, with wooden tables and benches that can be cleaned quickly and easily. Large windows allows one to enjoy the working surroundings, boats, birds, etc. On my departure, I usually buy take-aways to give to family and friends. If you see someone with a large cooler box, bound for Durban, at the airport - that's me.

Fish and Chips!. The fish and chips is wonderful at most places around here, Mariners Wharf, Fish on the Rocks and Snoekies. There are cute little craft markets as well, to walk off the food you just ate.
Great Vacation Spot. We spent our honeymoon in Hout Bay, staying at the old Castle. It was a dream! We love the harbor and the waterfront. Lots to see and do in the area.

Loved Hout Bay. Rather than stay in the hustle bustle of Cape Town, my husband and I chose to stay at Cube guest house 20 minutes away and loved the quiet and serene beauty. We had a car, so it was convenient to get around and made getting out to cape point easy as well. If you seek tranquility, you'll love Hout Bay.

No need of fancy bar..... We were sleeping at friends' but we enjoyed wonderful breakfasts with cappuccino and freshly made croissants or pies, at the Spar supermarket right on the corner! Comfy and cheaper, but super delicious!

Sitting at the dock of the bay. ...and while my time away. I used to sit here and meditate a bit, watching the ships come in and go by. Have a bite from one of the many take-aways offering seafood. An African art / souvenir shop was there too but may have closed now. Sometimes a male robben will push themselves up and jump up to the waterfront to lie in the sun and you can watch it. Boat tours are on offer every couple of hours and divers set out from here.

Spectacular views inside Greater Cape Town. Cape Town is the well known metropolis at the foot of Table Mountain. But Greater Cape Town has more to offer. One of the most beautiful trips is from Camps Bay (a Saint-Tropez like seaside resort on the Atlantic Coast) along the 12 Apostles mountain range to Hout Bay. A little detour might bring you to the tiny villige of Llandudno with its beautiful beach. Hout Bay is situated around a perfect crescent shaped bay and beach. Surrounded by mountains where the forest atmosphere makes you feel in a totally different area. And another beautiful short drive away from Constantia, heart of the Cape Town winelands.

Pretty Fishing Village. Houtbaai is a pretty sea side village with a large colony of seals living on a rocky outcrop just outside the harbour. These can be visited on one of the many boats that make a 40 minute return trip to view the seals.Warning - be careful with the group of men who feed the seals at the wharf for the tourists. If you take a picture they will expect a.payment and have been known to become very aggressive to people who take a picture but do not pay them.

Pretty . My husband grew up in Hout Bay so it was something of a trip down memory lane for him, and despite leaving 18 years ago, it still retains the feel of a small coastal town. It has a pretty beach and cute little main road with a surprising (for me) variety of shops and restaurants. We only stayed for about an hour but also had a drive around and the views are simply magnificent.

Dirty and Doggy. Now before the dog lovers jump on my head - I LOVE DOGS. I love that I can walk MY dog on this beach but the thing is that if you want to go for a walk without having some furry friend jump on you, bark at you, put a snotty snout in your hand or uhm, your private bits then this is not the beach for you.You can take your dog along to the restaurants too - like Dunes. Really great.There's lots of litter on the beach and the dunes of old seem to have disappeared.The little village of Hout Bay itself is always a treat. From the Hotel to the galleries to the good old faithful Wimpy - terrific. Just be warned that not all dog owners pick up poop and the beaches are dirty.

Beautiful Hout Bay. Visited the harbour and Bay Harbour Market and enjoyed a great breakfast and cup of coffee. Lots of choices for breakfast and lunch and interesting market stalls to browse. Beautiful drive over “Chappies” to finish the experience.

Unmissable . I loved that place!! U can eat fresh seafood, take a bout ticket and sail to see the wild seals, and I heard you can even dive with them! There is also a market there which is unmissable!!... You can buy almost anything there.. souvenir, shoes, clothes, home stuffs, flowers, etc. there are also places inside to have drinks, to eat well and to listen to live and fun music! Another good thing is that u see different kinds of people... Kids to elderlies, singles to families and different sways of dressing. I was there in march 2014.

Run down. This is really a place to catch a boat tour to seal island. The waterfront is really run down and boring. There is a mediocre native crafts mart in the open air. Don't get me wrong - the bay itself is still nice and whenever you can get a view it is a good one - not nearly as good as what lies ahead on the road, but very good. There was a huge fire that burned out everything on the road in, which I am told was very nice, but the town was saved.
Never need to go to Hout Bay. Hout Bay is looking terrible. The roads are falling apart, they are full of beach sand. The old harbour buildings are derelict and never mind the smell. Gosh....
travelled to cape town for holiday. loved the area, and the people, there was no rush for anything and people weere so friendly. Loved it in Hout Bay would definately go back again
Beautiful landscapes. The road along the sea from Cape of Good Hope to Hout bay is a must-see and must-do : landscapes are amazing.

Stop of for lunch on way back from the point. Depending on which was you drive to the point, we came back up the west side and stopped of at Hout Bay for lunch atr the Mariners Wharf.We had some King Sized prawns with the lemon sauce and the PeriPeri on the side, delicous..Whilst strolling on the beach later a seal came right up to the edge of the beach and nosed around for 5 minutes or so, great to see...

A lovely Saturday morning in Hout Bay. I had two hours to spare in the area and visited Hout Bay harbour. What a glorious way to spend a Saturday morning. I strolled along the harbour and simply enjoyed the sunshine and the abundant bird life. There were seals that came out for tasty morsels, being offered by the local fisherman. And to round off the outing...some delicious fish and chips.
Beautiful. We did the hop on/off bus tour that took us to Hout Bay. the views as you approach and leave the bay are beautiful.
a nice bay. We spent the afternoon in a house on a hill facing the bay. The view was beautiful. By the water, you can see a lot of seals.

Best old-school fish and chips. Every time we go to Hout Bay I have, what in my opinion is the best fish & chips ever! Fish 4 Africa is located amongst the docks and the locals eat there. For me that is a sign its great. Its lovely walking among the boats and down the beach. It is a beautiful place where one can easily loose your heart.

Absolutely Marvelous. I have always been a big fan of Hout Bay and can honestly recommend the brilliant little town to everyone visiting Cape Town. It is beautifully located with a magnificent welcome vibe to the town. The curio shop is amazing with a little bit of everything and anything for sale, perfect gifts to take back home to loved ones. Absolutely brilliant!
Picturesque location. Stopped by while driving from Cape Town Central to Cape of Good Hope. The bay itself is an amazing site by itself, a beautiful photo spot.

Food and craft market.great. At Hout Bay they have a fabulous food and craft market. The food variety is amazing and delicious. You must get there early, so you can park, then leave early to avoid the confusion. It sounds bad, but, the smell is disgusting as the crowds arrive. The sewer drain is right at front door. DONT LET THIS DETER YOU! We had the famous Lamb Man ciabatta buns. So yummy. Slow cooked leg of lamb with mint jelly, salad (if you want) and gravy saturated in the bun. The dim sum opposite the lamb man is also yummy. Heaps of varieties. There are cakes, sugar free, gluten free and they are delicious also. All in all it is a great day out. Alcohol available everywhere and all sorts of drinksJUST REMEMBER TO ARRIVE EARLY!!!

Stunning little village. We stopped at Hout Bay because of its beautiful beach nestled between the mountains on each side, with a backdrop of dunes behind. Taking off our shoes, we took a stroll down the beach watching the locals playing with their dogs while the children frolicked in the walter and built sand castles in the sand. A place where time has stood still. Just beautiful. Be aware, the Atlantic sea is cold and swimming is for the brave.

the most beautiful republic!. make sure to eat some fish & chips at the Warf , to just drive around for a while and appreciate the town, views, and beach! visit the harbour, and just hop from restaurant to coffee shop, to whine shop! impeccable value for money, with the best tastes and buys ever!!!

A piece of history in need of a clean up. A wonderful little town with a marm little harbour. But a bit of a clean up, and better signage would help. Little things like, toilet seat on the public toilets, etc would go a long way.

Popular with locals and tourists. Popular spot for locals and tourists, but can get overcrowded at the main restaurant. Small beach surrounded by mountains, seals, fishing boats, fresh seafood, pearls and tanzanite. Very family and pet friendly. Beautiful views.

..rather dirty and tacky... ..although Hout Bay is obviously a very wealthy neighbourhood the harbour area was very disappointing..it was dirty and overcrowded - it was Easter actually - there seemed no decent dining areas other than not very nice, simple food outlets..it was very difficult finding a decent spot and this was only achieved by taking a boat ride out to seal island..

Serene. I went to Hout bay buy bus 109 from town, its quite a small area compared to Camps Bay. The water is very clean, so swimmers are welcomed. Surrounded by views of the mountains and valleys from both sides. There are also a number of restaurant few meters from the beach, so make a perfect afternoon.

A whole day outing. You can do so very much here. Take a boat to seal island, shop or get fish and chips.. Don't miss the pearl shop ladies - you can buy an oyster and they open it in front of you to get the pearl and if you are lucky you might get twins. Then you can put them in a basket chain for your neck. Lovely, lovely day for all

180 degree of nice panoramic view. The place is like small fishing port with very excellent place to take lunch. The water here is pure and if you want to have some fun you will find person or two feeding seal...

Bit disappointing. parking is chaotic particularly on a weekend and or 'beach day'. Place is rather dirty and restaurants run down. Nice to access the docks and see the seals, apart from that better places to visit.

Nice day tour. Nics to visit Hout Bay, all the historic shops, markets and a must do is to get some fresh fish take away or at one of the local restaurants. Walk on the harbour wall during a sunset is so beautiful...the colours of the boats and sky, spectacular

Stunning and breath taking views. It was amazing and so pretty. The oceans look stunning from here and the drive all the way from Constantia to Hout Bay is really worth it purely for the view of the ocean.

nice day at the beach!!. this was my favorite beach town!! I would love to come back and stay for few days there! quaint little beach town with few restaurants, bar, shops.. it was a little bit chilly to stay on the beach but we had a walk and drinks at a cafe.

Still the same. Have been a few times over the years but i feel the harbour area needs a new life again. Like a revamp , waters looking dirtier than before. Otherwise it was just than same as my previous visits.

Seales. Lots of Seals and Nice boattrips, special atmosphere typical for a Harbour, interesting place to go, the drive from,Capetown only takes up,to 20 minuten and you can get there with the blue line of the hop on hop off

Stunning. Popular with locals ,for visitors this is a must.
Hout Bay is a small village by the Sea .
Eat the best Fish and Chips ,take a boat ride to Seal Island and spot the great white shark .
Mix with local Fisherman and Town Ship Residents .
Great Market,Restaurants,Shops .
Local is Lekka as they say.

Fish and chips paradise. If you enjoy traditional fish and chips meals, Snoekies in Hout Bay harbour is the place to go to. Scale it up and you can opt for many of the good restaurants to be found in the area. A great meal must be followed up with a scenic drive around Chapman's Peak to reach your hotel room in the City center.

Houts Bay harbour is still in a lovely setting but has not benefitted from its tourism potential. We felt the the village was suffering from a lack of development. The fishing industry has been though hard times and some of the life seemed to have gone out of the place. The fish and chips were still as good as they were 20 years ago but the fish market was also the same as 20 years ago with the sign inside still saying 'no photographs' on the only artifacts in the place worth photographing. Good for a lunch time break but no longer worth a day lazily exploring
Love. I love Hout Bay!! Especially the market on fridays, saturdays and sundays. The food is delicious and I never leave empty handed.
A must visit when in cape town. A fihermans village set in a beautiful picture like setting.You can see the seals in the harbour and there is restaurants and curio shops.
Great Little Coastal Fishing Town. We drove through heading down to the Cape from Cape Town. Didn't stop in town, but got some excellent photographs from one of the view point just outside town.
a little gem. Stunning little gem we did snorkelling with the seals from here and it was so beautiful although can get busy with tourists by lunchtime

Simply Beautiful!. Hout Bay us a worthy stop on your visit to Cape Town, If you are taking the hop-on hop- off bus, just get off at the stop and enjoy a beautiful beach, lovely little boardwalk with colorful fishing boats, and a couple of great places to get your fish and chips. Beautiful and relaxing. Don't forget to look up the hill behind you for an excellent view of the castle!

Worth a stop - to have a look at the fishing port and market if open. Hout Bay offers some great photo opportunities, if your are doing the Cape Point tour. It is worth following the bay around to the actual fishing port. There are a few good fish restaurants here and a nice beach that sweeps around the whole bay and a great place to walk. While we were there we saw sea-lions by the fishing boats. There is also a small shopping centre if you need to stock up on food items etc.
A great place for lunch. We stopped and had a lovely seafood lunch on the way back from the Cape of Good Hope. A lovely beach to wonder along.
Coastal town. Stunning little coastal town about 30 mins outside Capetown. Famous for its seafood and crayfish. Nice wide beach. Plenty of shops.
Amazing view. Very nice fish harbour village with amazing views over the bay and the mountain. Nice restaurants and great food.

Nice town to visit. There was a working harbour to walk around. Little cafe to get a coffee and delicious crunchie biscuits. At weekends there is a market selling souvenirs. At the other end of the beach is a statue of a cheetah overlooking the bay. Also the Dunes restaurant is very good, casual and reasonable prices. There is also a small shopping mall with a large Pick N Pay supermarket and Woolworths supermarket.
Quaint. Stopped off for an ice cream which was good; not too sure about the man feeding the seal for 'tips'!

A beautiful beach but lots of dog mess. We visited Hout bay on 2 occasions. The market in the harbour is great offering a wide array of crafts and also food stalls where you can try some delicious African specialties and gourmet food, at the other side of the bay, the beach is a beautiful crescent shape with numerous people paddle boarding and kayaking in the sheltered bay. On the other hand there hoards of dog walkers who don;t pick up their dogs mess so you have to watch where you walk on the beach which has you looking at the sand all the time. not the beautiful views. We were lucky enough to witness a pod of dolphins enter the bay during our visit and watch them play in the waters. At the end of Hout Bay is Chapmans Peak Drive which is a beautiful coastal road that is well worth the small toll for the spectacular views. It takes you to Norkhoek which has the most spectacular super-wide sandy beach.

"Rhinocerous" mountain/island view. Another gorgeous view in the Cape Town area! This bay has stunning blue and turquoise water surrounded by mountains (ncluding the Rhinocerous looking portion) and valley. We happened to see four tourist boats racing around in circles in the water too, quite entertaining.

Beautiful place to hang out on Sunday. I loved my visit to Hout Bay. It is the one place I would live in if I was to move to Cape Town. It has the feel of a small yet busy town. There is a nice beach with surfers and people playing with their dogs. I got to see some seal as well. We had lunch at the Mariners Wharf twice. I love the food there. It really is a charming little town
Good place to see Eel and Sea Gulls. A must visit as Capetonians would recommend. Has interesting history to support. Very nice views all around.
not sure how to rate this?. Hout Bay in general is increadibly average. The locals are unfriendly and the beaches are shocking. meh
quiet little fishing port. We got off the red bus for 30 minutes at most but got the whole life of this little fishing port. We saw a couple of otters there.

Very nice, calm and serene experience. We stayed there for an evening and enjoyed every moment of it.
Sitting by the beach made me feel so relaxed and happy. Although the wind was so cold that it chilled my bones for 2-3 days...
Apart from that I thoroughly enjoyed it and would love to visit this nice town again :)
Scenic. Very picturesque bay not far from Cape Town. A pleasant drive and beautiful vistas. Take a picnic and enjoy the scenery.
A look lovely fishing village. A great place for a coffee stop. Lots of coffee shops. A craft market and a cute seal on the quay. Locals gutting fish remember to pay them for photography.

Just Absolutely Beautiful. Apart from some strange "sea" smells! What amazing place/view/heritage! Always enjoy visiting and always find new beautiful sights to see! A stroll on the beach, traditional fish and chips, the crafts market and indoor market...all super features and all worth a visit!

A beautiful to visit and admire. When we got there, the weather was truly weird. Fantastic color on the near waters, and grey dark skies hiding the other side of the bay. The bonus were the cute sea lions who paid a visit and ate some fish from a local's mouth.
BEAUTIFUL!. Part of our bus tour - what views! We were lucky with the weather - we saw the Bay at its best. Enjoy and well worth a visit. Thank You!
Fun place to get local feel. Nice drive from Cape Town, fun to see the local fishing trade. Can stop on the way to several other places of interest.
Lovely View. Small town with beautiful view of Atlantic Ocean on one side and Table Mountain Range on other side. Laid back atmosphere. Ideal place to relax and spend a day.

Blue water...Small Seal Island...Great place for Souvenirs. Hout Bay is a beautiful place. Walk along the sand, the wind across the ocean and a boat ride to the small Seal island was memorable. This place is very good for South African souvenirs, you can bargain to bring down the prices. The same souvenirs at other established shops (eg: ones at V&A waterfront) would cost much much more.

Fish and chips and a veiw of the ocean.... Have a good sit down and eat upstairs at Mariners warf or opt for a cheaper fish and chips option downstairs... eat and see the ocean flow passed the mountains and there are seals to watch too, they know some tricks as well

Blue water and lots of birds. I'm a bird lover. Anytime I can stop by a beach--particularly one as beautiful as this--I will. Hout Bay is a beautiful place. Walk along the sand, smell the ocean, and get stung by the tremendous wind that rushes across the highways. It doesn't matter. It's all worth it.

Hout Bay Tour. Hout's Bay a very important fishing village they have a canning factory for rock lobster, and a fish meal plant as well as a fresh fish market. They also have the largest bird sanctuary in South Africa and the second largest in the worldFrom the Harbour you can take a Boat tour out to Duiker Island( Seal Island) to photograph the Cape Fur seal colony you will see 100's of seals frolicking in the water and hundreds more layingon the rocks sunning them selfs. You can smell these seals from the boatDM.WB

Good place to shop for souvenirs. We went on a boat ride to see the seals. You can actually see them from the shore without even boarding a boat. This place is very good for shopping as there are lots of South African souvenirs you can see at a much cheaper prices.The best part? You can haggle especially if you're going to buy a lot. So better buy as a group so you can get them cheaper.

White beach & cozy fisherman's wharf . Great view of the bay and the Chapmans Peak Drive. Seals in the harbor and a fleet of active fishing boats. A cozy and authentic wharf with seafood restaurants and shops selling fresh seafood, wine and other delicacies. Great for a lunch outside the city.

Best days to visit Hout Bay. Certainly worth a visit and within 20 minutes drive from Cape Town. There are interesting boat trips from the harbour to seal island but I would recommend going there on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday as the Craft Fair is held on these days. The Fair is full of varied crafts from jewellery, clothes, accessories,souvenirs.etc. etc. and the food stands have a great selection of both local and international cuisine. If you are lucky in your timing you will be entertained by musicians, both on stage and the South African equivalent to a trad band !!

excellent. Hout Bay got everything what yu will need on a nice holiday; good and comfortable accommodation, exellent restaurants, supermarket, etc..., Hout Bay is safe and cozy and has a great beach. I really like to recommend this place.

Go to the market, but get there early. Wow food, all home made. Gotta try the biltong no matter if you come from Joies or Alaska. Also you must see the sculptures made from old bits and pieces, what a privilege to see such an artist. Pity you can't put them into your luggage ....

Great place to visit.... Probably not the best beach around, but definitely one to visit. There is so much to,do here. The Harbour makes a great visit and the markets are great. There are plenty of little restaurants to explore and scenic views along the way. A great tip is to stop overnight.....I am sure you will want to return, even if just to spend some time at the Mariners Wharf.....Lobster is excellent!

A little billage that delivers. So much to,do here. Visit the harbour and markets, especially on the weekends. There are some gorgeous shops here, little gems that deserve patronage. Lots of little restaurants to explore, scenic views along the way, easy to spend time here and come away wanting to return.

Gorgeous. I love Hout Bay. We visited Hout Bay when I was a youngster at the age of 12 and it left a vivid picture in my memory.I did not remember where this place was or the name of it. When we arrived in February 15 it came back to me. This place is beautiful and I could spend all day chilling looking around this area. This is my favourite place in Cape Town.The Mariners Wharf is a must if you visit Hout Bay. Best fish I have ever eaten. I am not a fish person but when I go there again I will be having the line fish of the day again. The tuna was amazing....

Small Little Wonder Beach. Houtbay is most probably not the best beach that Cape Town and surroundings has to offer. It's relaxing and will allow you to soak up the sun while enjoying the silhouette of mountains on the horizon. Make sure to grab a bottle of good old red wine from a local vineyard that is not to far away and cheers to one of the most beautiful sunsets that you will ever seen.

Interesting Place. The town is still a fishing town and is a little run down, but it is very scenic, and is a good place to stop if you on the way to or from the cape of good hope. You can get excellent fish and chips here.

The best snoek and chips in the Cape. The 'Snoek and Chips' take-away has the best fish and chips in Cape Town. It is where the locals buy their fish take-aways and is therefor much better and cheaper than at the Mariners Wharf. Any local in Hout Bay of one of the Bella-taxi's will be able to tell you where it is. Just travel past the Mariners Wharf and the road ends in a Cul de Sac in front of the shop. The warehouse across from the shop also houses the Hout Bay Market, that sell amazing food, wines, clothing, jewelery and has alive band on Friday nights.Also make sure to visit the harbor and if you see an old man with a white beard feeding some of the seals, chat to him, he has an interesting story. :)
We enjoyed the Seal Island boat ride. Thousands of seals viewed on Seal Island from the boat. Our 9 year old grand daughter had a great time, too.
Breathtaking view. Breathtaking view of the bay with a backdrop of the Table mountain. Gives unhindered view with sun set being excellent.

Very very cool!. Very cheap souvenirs. Cheapest we found anywhere in South Africa but no less quality. If we had known, we would have bought more there. Took an inexpensive ferry ride to seal island (where Shark Week is filmed) and saw literally thousands of seals. Even adorable baby seals swimming next to the boat. The views from the ferry were breathtaking. It's a rough ride over to seal island but very short (only 10-15 min.)
A great market - come hungry. The Hout Bay market that is open on the weekends has wonderful crafts and also great food vendors. Don't miss it.
Liked it very much.. They have a great restaurant there mariners wharfe you do need to book nothing much else there be careful after dark.

Plenty to do here!. This is a great little town with a nice little Market and you can get a boat to see the Sentinal be warned it will be an exilarating ride it gets pretty bouncy but you will see Seal Island too worth a trip out for sure!
A must visit place of anyone going to Cape town. The most beautiful beach to walk along, buzzing atmosphere in the small harbour and a great place for fish and chips!
Windy. Nice sandy beach, but sandstorm often appears due to the wind. The water was really when we visited, but the sun was nice!

Take the Seal Island Cruise. The big draw in Haut Bay is the Seal Island Cruise. Well worth the nominal fee the 30 minute cruise takes. Thousands of seals out on seal rock. The subsequent drive up through Chapman's peak overlooking the bay is spectacular.
very scenic!. Great seafood restaurant at Hout Bay. Lovely views over the Atlantic Ocean with fishing boats & white sandy beach.

Little treasure. beautiful beach, friendly locals. Lots of choice for eating out. Some really good meals ragafellows and sporos to name 2 of our favourites. Enough shops to buy any must have items. Laid back feel.

Just like English Old Fashioned Seaside Town. Small beach and bay. Fellow there who feeds the seals and calls them by name. He will happily oblige for a few Rand!
Great fish and chips.

Friday night market. Awesome little market on Fridays, good food, good drinks and lots of interesting art, crafts, clothing and more. Try to avoid if you dont like big crowds, this place was packed! Still very enjoyable.

HOUTBAY MARKET - FOOD FUN FASHION. If you are looking to an alternative place to go on a Friday evening or over the weekend , Houtbay Market is the place to go . So much to do fabulous food from Asian , Italian Pizza , German Sausages , Sushi , Gourmet Bugers , Steak wraps , Soup . Then you have all the desserts , Milktart , Red Velvet Cupcakes , Muffins . Then for the thirsty ones you have craft beers , cocktails , and a bar with normal wine beer and Champange . That's just the food section . You will have live music , and all the stands to browse for clothing , soaps , jewellery , vinyl records . Guys just go and explore , and enjoy .

First for fish and chips!!. We never fail to visit Hout Bay when in SA simply for Hake and Chips at Fish on the Rocks. Don't expect luxury but DO expect the best fish ever. The craft market is interesting and lively and if you don't like fish and chips there are plenty of good food alternatives to choose from. Don't miss a visit to the galleries next door which can be easily missed but have some fabulous art and crafts.
Worth the Drive. We were in Cape Town for several days and had our own car and toured all around. Please do drive along the coast and visit Hout Bay, beautiful views and right on the ocean.

Perfect Landscape. Hout Bay is a lovely bay and it is so difficult to keep driving in front of so lush landscapes. Makes you want to stop the car every curve how beautiful is the composition of the landscape. It is also the place where you take the boat to de Seal Island.

wow. This is the place to visit if you're in Cape Town. I was really impressed about the Hout Bay Harbour, so good restaurants, you can play with the seals and what was amassing for us is that we taste some real fresh tuna sashimi right there near the boats. Really different that what you can taste in restaurant.

Great market and harbor.... Jumped off the hop on hop off bus here and walked around the harbor as well as the market for a while. both were interesting and a good way to spend some time. The sand dunes and beach were very nice, except the wind was blowing very hard and we got a bit sandblasted. Im not a fish eater, but everyone said the fish was very good. We didn't stay too long, but there is plenty to see and do here for a few hours. It would have been nice if the whales were in season, then we would have stayed longer.

The bay & Harbour of Hout Bay. A visit to this wonderfully busy working harbour is a must. Even the sunken wrecks moored against the piers are of interest. There is an active fishing industry as well as both commercial & private boats on the move. Entertainment is provided by the seal population. With of course a good fish meal to be had in one of the restaurants there.
Great town! . Beautiful town with so much to do! We enjoyed all the activities around the harbour especially the market. Always a stop whenever we are in Houtbay.

Beautiful white sand whipped beaches and dunes only a few miles from Cape Town!. Recommended.Take a drive along the coast from Cape Town and you'll follow the road down to Hout Bay. The vista's and twists of the road along this route are akin to driving along US Route 1 in California.ON arrival at Hout Bay, you'll see a quaint beach side town featuring gorgeous white sand beaches and dunes caressing a somewhat turbulent blue water islet from the ocean. The town presents a variety of shops and restaurants. It's worth a visit.

Great beach for walking. Hout Bay is on the north side of the Chapmans Peak Drive. Quieter than Camps Bay so better for families. Very good modern shopping centre. Enough restaurants and coffee shops to provide variety. Interesting craft market open on Friday late afternoon onwards and Saturday / Sunday all day. The beach is lovely for a walk and the early morning and evenings is dog walking time!

A pretty seaside town with plenty to do. Hout Bay has good shopping and restaurants, an interesting port and seafront, and a great indoor market with food on Fridays and Saturdays evenings. You can find almost anything you want in a very relaxed seaside atmosphere.

Hout bay. We stayed in Llandudno just around the corner from Hout Bay, the village itself is sweet and pretty, but we felt the squatter camp was a bit of a put off. there are plenty of supermarkets here and some shops. The best thing we found was the Dunes restaurant at 1 Beach road we returned 3 times! The restaurants on the harbour are also very nice but more touristy.There is a lovely craft market on Sundays, best of all was the lady with the local cotton knitted jerseys, I came home with 3!
lovely!. I would recommend going on Sunday for the market! If you get there early before the crowd it is even better! Fish on the rocks is a must when you are in Hout Bay.

Seals for a bargain!. Many tourism outfits will try to sell you a trip to seal island. These trips leave from several harbors on the peninsula south of Cape Town. The fact is that you can do this on your own and add some spectacular views of the ocean. Many boats offer to take you to seal islands for about 7 dollars per person. Along the dock, some of the seals have been trained by locals to jump out of the water and take a piece of fish from the locals' mouth. This might not be something you want to try by yourself but it is quite fun to watch. The road (toll but cheap) brings you to the Cape of Good Hope. Spectacular spot with ostriches and sea birds on the way.
Food it what I think of when Hoot Bay is mentioned. One of the best Indian Restaurants in Africa on the seafront and excellent Fish and Chips at the harbour
Nice place. Here you can go out with special boats to see seals, and there are a lot of them. It´s a quite a nice Place to visit and you can do it on your way Good Hope.

endless beauty. Awesome views and plenty to do ,eating fish ,Ice cream at the most delicious Italian Ice cream for a quaint shop Fishing boats and Seals .A beautiful beach to take a walk and endless views of the ocean. A ride by car or a climb up the famous Chapman's peak is very necessary

Beautiful town.. best location for crayfish and snoek fish industry. This is a beautiful town and is always kissed by the beautiful beach. Water is calm and the houses are beautifully spaced and placed.

Charming. As small towns go, this one is really small. Located at the end of long scenic drive in a sheltered bay, the heart of this town is the harbour with its many, colorful boats & the occassional seal surfacing to try its luck with tourists. There's nothing much to do here except take a boat ride to watch seals & other marine life or sit at one of the many restaurants overlooking the harbour & enjoy the view. Still, its worth a visit

Best place on a Sunday!. If you love to shop and if you love to find really precious items for little money.. I say go here! Sundays is market day. An old fish warehouse (no it doesn't smell) is opened up with more than a 100 booths adorned with arts, crafts, merchandise.. Found some beautiful hand crafted bowls for my home, gorgeous jewelry, sunglasses, clothing.. All for under a few hundred. And when you get tired of shopping, then you can do lots of people watching.  We went to Hout Bay twice. The second time, we walked along the pier with old beautiful boats, saw men feeding seals (literally putting fish in their mouth's and seals would jump out of the water and grab the fish.), We walked along a beautiful beach with panoramic views and ended up having a lovely little lunch at Dunes Beach restaurant. Great day!

Nice area to explore. of course your need a car. There is lots to see and do. Cape Good Hope ect. Beautifull drives. Ignore the buses at Cape Good hope and their ' struggle' to make a picture at the sign.Walk up and enjoy the view. It's steep, so not everyone will do this.

Attractive fishing harbour. Well worth a visit, and a meal at Mariners Wharf is a must. Try the Kingklip with garlic butter sauce, on the outside veranda. Also there are very enjoyable, and ridiculously cheap, one hour boat rides.

Simple life. No excitements, but nice and family friendly.
A few good restaurants and a somehow clean beach
not crowded and there is no big rush here if you are not catching the market on a saturday
Great Fish Bites. Loved the Market. Loved the scenery and the Bay. Loved The Fish Shop. I had The Bites. My partner had the Crayfish and Chips. Great Morning. Go.
Liquor shop. Every year once landed we go to Hout bay to the liquor shop for unbeatable prices on all alcoholic brands. We also buy a lot of gifts in the pearl shop.

strawl along the coast. A beautiful beach went the wind is gone. The view are magnificent. Be careful though where the river Disa is, this river is heavily polluted.
Other main attraction in Hout bay is Hout Bay Harbour Crafts market.

Hout Bay is a must see!. Hout Bay has its problems as there is a lot of poverty and the population live on the main roads. Kids are everywhere and you need to drive with caution. Having said that there is much for the traveler from food to sightseeing. Visit this place - you wont regret the trip.
famous place. It is an important point on cape peninsular tour especially b'cause ferry goes from here to seal island.There are small wayside shops selling local stuff.

Nice location, not much to do.. We stopped here for lunch on the City Sightseeing bus tour. There is a nice beach area, a few restaurants and some stores/vendors selling wood carvings and other tourist stuff but not much else to do here. There are a few local fisherman who feed the seals for entertainment.
Lovely typical fisherman's village ambiance. Great food at great prices, the good old trafic all fish & chips is superb, on week ends good entertainer also. Love the place!

cheap boat trips to the seals. We stayed one afternoon in hout bay and really liked the atmosphere there. Children playing around, some small stands to buy african art, a show with a seal, good food (calamari & chips) in a nice take away stand and really a funny and cheap tour to the seals and back. Perfect afternoon

A bit touristy. Lovely old fishing town. A bit touristy with locals feeding the fur seals and collecting money for the privilege. Had an excellent meal at a restaurant called The Lookout. Would recommend!
S Africa 2015. An interesting town with a good harbour and waterfront. The shops are interestingand not large chains, good African stalls for purchasing souvenirs.

a bit different. a bit different from the rest of the bays in the area, it is a port and offers fish restaurant or cruises.
the seal cruise is a quick but enjoyable experience if the sea is not swollen.
Try the fish billtong

Great fishing harbour close to Cape Town. A very relaxed pleasant environment. We had a leisurely lunch at a restaurant, right on the water. Watched the seals frolicking in the water in front of the restaurant window. Beautiful scenic surroundings with the mountain and ocean. There are many souvenir stalls, with good variety. Definitely worth a drive from Cape Town.

Unexpected Beauty. We were not expecting to go here on the day that we did. The water is very cold but there were people in it anyway. There is a beautiful drive into Hout Bay that is carved into the mountain. It is an unforgettable experience.
Went to the Seals. We took the boat out to see Seal Island. It was definitely worth it. Recommended if you're into wildlife.
Fish and Chips!. We stopped in Hout Bay on the way to see Chapman's Peak. There is a Fish and Chips place on the water that was amazing. Super busy, but worth the wait.
remote. Good food, yes, but either you come by bus and hold up all commuters, or come after rush our. And I refuse to write at leaset 50 characters. My hand are tired from typing already.

Lovely place for a stroll and a bite to eat. We took the hop-on-hop off sightseeing bus and spent a few hours here. Lovely beach and not too busy. The boardwalk was also not too crowded, and you can also browse the stalls if you would like to do a bit of shopping (though rather overpriced and good negotiation skills are necessary!). Also had lunch in the fish and chips place by the boardwalk -highly recommended!

Good day out. Lovely place ,if your looking for a trip on a boat out to see the seals ,or just feel like dipping in the ocean ,it has both of those ,lots of parking around there are a few restaurants available ,a must for any tourist visiting the cape
Nice visit. The beach is very nice , not overly busy and the Marina resturant had a great lunch for the price. Enjoyed the bird sanctuary.

Great stop on the Blue Bus Tour. We took the Blue Bus Tour from Long Street and stopped off along the way at pretty well all the places to see. And Hout Bay was a great experience. We watched fishermen unloading their catch on he pier. Bought beautiful pearl earrings at an interesting shop at the entrance to the harbour. Watched the seals taking small bits of fish from the teeth of enterprising locals. Strolled along the stalls on the waterfront. Had ice cream. We didn't get much beyond the harbour area before it was time to jump back on the Blue Bus - but we had a very pleasant 90 minutes here. We'll come for longer the next time we visit South Africa.

Hout Bay. It was amazing, ultimate experience would love to visit once more It was amazing, ultimate experience would love to visit once more It was amazing, ultimate experience would love to visit once more It was amazing, ultimate experience would love to visit once more It was amazing, ultimate experience would love to visit once more

A nice day spot, see the seaside and mountains on same trip. A cab drive from CPT city centre via Kirstenbosch and return via Hout Bay was reasonably priced R 500 for two people. Money well spent! Could add also a visit to a winery nearby if needed to the same trip.

Market on the Water Front. If you are looking for African arts and crafts, the Market on the Hout Bay Water Front is an excellent place to shop. The building is near "Fish on the Rocks" where you can also stop for a quick lunch. If you go by cab, get the drivers number so he can come back for you. The traffic is heavy, with locals looking for parking, so don't assume you will easily find a cab back to your hotel.

BUSY AREA. Visited with my family jan 2015.This is a very busy area,with lots of places to eat,if you love fish and chips ,then this is the area for you.Try the fish shop at the end of the road or Snookies.

Interesting little town. We drove here and walked through the harbour area. We ate the freshest fried calamari we have ever had from one of the little booths in the harbour, delicious. We also took the boat out to Seal Island - a great place to see seals in their natural habitat. You don't have to pay for your parking in the carp ark and you can also get here on the Blue Bus

Absolutely beautiful. The drive up Chapmans Peak that will take you through and then above Hout Bay is worth it on a sunny day. Astounding views down into the bay. Nature, fresh air and photo opportunities abound

Hout Bay. take the Blue sight seeing bus route and get off at Hout Baywe had lunch in the resturant on the water side next to where the boats run taking people out to seal Island food was very good value for money and i would eat their again.we walk around the harbour watching the locals feeding the Cape Fur Seals if you take pictures of the please pay them 10 or 20 rand we got some amazing photos, we also took the large blue boat trip to seal island worth £10 each hundreds of seals, it was rough but well worth it as was my whole experince of visiting Cape Town

Scenic coastal town. we had a short stop in this quint town nestled between the sea and the mountains of the cape. It was late afternoon and things were winding down for the day, but it still had a great vibe to it. A must place to go if you want to eat seafood.
Great views. Great views for tourists to visit (I brought a large group here), good food and wine in abundance and a lovely beach to stroll down.
Souvenires and Seals.. What a great surprise, seals jumping up to catch their fish from the mouths of men and lovely, handmade curios.
lovely little town. loved it here so pleasant to wander around and had fab lunch at the Brass Bell. Parking was easy and lots of quirky shops.

Mariners Warfe. We were well looked after in the restaurant by Conrad who was most friendly and attentive.
Go onto the pier and look out for the man who has a seal taking fish from his mouth, amazing! Make sure to give him some money.

Mariners' Wharf. The MyCiti bus service now goes right to the door and anyone who doesn't visit this iconic venue while in Cape Town doesn't know seafood. While the places close to the beach are very good, nothing beats Snoekies on the far side of the harbour.
Dont miss!. Beautiful view. Dont miss this on the way to cape point. Nice restaurants around. Good to go to fish on the rocks
A must see. Hout Bay is a must see when in Cape Town, including Chapmans Peak. It is a great spot for a picnic also.

A very beautiful bay with tour boats. The bay is rugged and has rocks at the entrance which is home to thousands of seals. There is some residential development here, though for the most part it is undeveloped. Clean and attractive, worth a visit.
Awesome destination!. Hout Bay is known for awesome food! There are many amazing, small take aways for fish and chips etc. It is also a very clean beach but very popular.
YUMMM YUMM Fish and Chips. the most divine fish n chips by Snoekies can be found at Hout Bay, get your souveniours and be part of this experience which can ONLY be found in Cape Town !

ferry ride. place to take ferries from multiple options available. you can see hout bay area from sea side which u actually see from chapman peak road side as well. they also have glass floor type ferries which take u to seal island. evening cruise are nice with high waves.
Fish and Chips. Mariners Wharf - Pricey but pretty tasty! I have a feeling they increase prices in Summer due to tourists!

Do mot understand the who-ha about Hout Bay. Hout Bay is really not the star for me. It is a small town, with a funny lay out and a dirty beach.
For me Hout Bay is a way to get up or down form Chapman's Peak drive.

Beautiful, small South African town. This was the first stop on a day tour from Cape Town. Quaint town. Visitors can take a boat to visit a seal island but we have already seen seals like these, so we spent the time walking around the harbour. There was a market with locals selling their crafts for souvenirs. There are plenty of cafés. There was also a man getting seals to jump out of the water to take the fish sticking out of his mouth(for a tip of course). It also happened to be the day Oscar Pistorious was sentenced, so very interesting hearing the reaction of the South African people. If you are driving yourself, Hout Bay beach looked beautiful.

Great place for fish and chips. If you want good fish and chips , then head to Hout Bay Mariners Wharf . Apart from great food , it is a great working harbour with regular visits of the seals . Kids would love to see these friendly animals show their tricks . There is a nice beach but would recommend supervision if you want to swim . My number 1 food choice for good wholesome food - please try the calamarie and crab sticks whilst at Mariners . You can also visit some of the little shops - little pearl studs for R45 - a great buy at the store . In the village itself there are a few factory stores which you might enjoy .

Idyllic Harbour. We had visited Hout Bay as part of the city sight seeing tour; it was definitely worth it!You are able to walk all along the harbour wall and be surrounded by beautiful Cape Townian scenery. There are fantastic markets on Fridays, Saturdays and Sunday's where you can pick up authentic South African crafts as souvenirs.Mariners Warf is a pirate ship styled restaurant complex where you can get some great seafood dishes.Whilst we were there, there had been a minor domestic argument between a fisherman and his wife; they had been arguing about the fish they were feeding the seals with (a must see by the way). It got quite dramatic, rusty fish knives were swung and glass bottles were thrown. Fortunately there is an abundance of security staff there and the situation dissipated quickly.

Disappointing and dirty. the Barbour is a great place to see the seals close up but it was filthy and you are constantly harassed by tramps. The smell of urine is overwhelming and whilst the area is beautiful, it certainly does not fit with the cleanliness elsewhere in Cape Town.

Fun times. Hout bay is wonderful for a day trip if you have time. You must try the fish once there - Mariners Wharf is a hit, and sit on the beach outside the restaurant after for a relaxed day. It is a very calm beach so its pleasant. Round the corner from there is a craft market where you can find items for dirt cheap - like under R20 even! Also, the hop-on hop-off gets off right here so its super convenient :)

A down-to-earth little fishing outpost. When we stopped for lunch here at the end of our tour on the red Cape Town sightseeing bus, Hout Bay was heaving. Local children and families were splashing in the sea and tourists were queuing for tables at the restaurants, most of which serve freshly caught fish and seafood. It's a jolly little place. Much more down-to-earth and ramshackle than its snootier Camps Bay neighbour. Worth a stop off if you're on the mini blue peninsula tour bus.

Beautiful but Read Up. Hout Bay is lovely, but it is overcrowded and there are a few places you can do well to avoid. Snoekies and Mariners are the famous places, but they just serve fried calamari and prawns and you can do well to stay away, unless you are desperate to fill your stomach.There are some great places to drink and eat away from the harbour. This is where you go for a gourmet meal. The harbour is a working harbour and its worth going around there between 4 and 6pm to see the fishermen bring in in their catch.There are also seals in the bay, and a local beggar does shows where he feeds the seals and allows you to also feed the seals.Its entertaining and very real.

nice place to take a drive to. Great place for the seafood lovers - mariners wharf
Seal Island trip - 40min boat ride
Nice beach, Only 3 roads into this village - chapmans peak drive is sensational, constantia nek drive is tree lined and gorgeous... and of course the only other road out is via llundudno... so sights for the soul.
A dump.. Never enjoy this hole. Seems to be full of stuck up unfriendly types who hide away as if on a dodgy island. Probably they are. Avoid it like the plague.

seal island boat ride. definitely worth a visit
lots of restaurants and curio shops around the harbour
enjoyable day trip
Snoekies reccomended for their fresh fish, but quality seemsto be waning
Hout bay. A nice place to stop on the way to Cape Point - cape of Good Hope. Nice beach and picturesque bay but it can get crowded.

So central, South to do!!. Wonderful time spent in Hout Bay Western Cape. So many interesting things to do in Hout Bay itself. Good eateries in particular Katima and Quentin's @Oakhurst Farm. Harbour food market on Fridays and dunes for sundowners. Also sundowners on rocks at Llundadno - amazing. Not far from gym in Constantia and an hour from wonderful wine lands. Giavanni's at Eikendal Farm also worth a visit especially go lunch - beautiful setting.
Beautiful. Stopped here on way to Cape Point and found this place to be a quaint little fishing village. The views back into Hout Bay from the coastal mountain roads are just stunning.

Good fishing village. This is good fishing village with a good beach ,enjoyed a lovely swim on hot day as waters can be a bit cold.Grab lunch from Mariners Wharf and enjoy it and beach ,not as crowded as other Cape town beaches which was enjoyable

Fishermans Wharf- interesting for families. Go in the morning by about 10am and watch the fishermen unloading all their boats- we saw (literally) truck loads of tuna being unloaded. Good craft market in the port too- and great fish and chips as you would expect.

Cape Town's best kept secret. great beach and restaurants in the area. Stay in a B&B to make the most of Houtbay's magic! Restaurants and tourist shopping spots are every where at Houtbay's Marina. NOT a fan of the traffic.. township drivers can make the main road on the tourist strip a walking nightmare.

Great views, stunning properties but not really for kids. We stayed in Hout Bay for 10 days with a bunch of friends in a lovely house overlooking the bay. Wonderful views and a nice beach to walk along a couple of times a day but the amount of dog poop on the sand and absolutely no effort on the part of dog owners to pick it up is disappointing. The sea is freezing so not much use for kids. Some nice restaurants in the town and the working fishing port is nice to stroll around even if it is rather run down. We did the sea fishing which was a bit of a dead loss and very expensive. Not an awful lot to do, but we managed a bunch of day trips away from the place for interest. As other have said, almost all of the beaches around are better. Great fish and chips at Salties.

Beautiful setting. Beautiful location with great seafood selection. You can also do boat tours from Hout Bay. You can view the boats coming in with their catches and even buy fresh fish. There is a curio shop where you can buy gifts. The beach is also lovely and you can go for a lovely swim. Hout Bay is a short distance drive to Chapman's Peak where the drive along the cliffs is breath taking.

Loved it!. SA friends told us to head here! Escape the crowds grab take-out fish and chips, find a quiet spot and enjoy. We found gorgeous fish&chips, sat and watched the world go by...bliss.Head to the harbour and we were treated to seals in the bay been fed by the locals.Plenty of shops, market, bars and restaurants along the front also.Lovely morning wish we could have stayed longer.

Fresh fish and pearl shop. Marine Wharf and the take away down stairs have fantastic fresh fish/ seafood. A BIG serving! The chips are more than a portion for one at the take away. there are tables and benches to sit and have your food if you prefer the take away which we usually do.Although the pearls that are sold in the shop next to the take away are not from South Africa it is still a lovely memorabilia to take home.Great scenery! Stop on your way through Chapman's Peak. Amazing experience!

Unspoilt beach as I remember it. Great beach for a long unspoilt walk, swim if you don't mind cold water too. Lot's of restaurants and shops to see in Hout Bay too well worth a visit. One of my favourite places in the Cape.

Scenic but not sure it's an actual destination point. Went through Hout's Bay on the way to Boulder Beach. Nice scenery. Some places of lodgings and shopping but wouldn't make a special trip there unless that is your final destination. Just didn't seem to be anything but another suburb. If you have limited time, would only see it if intermediate stop.

Dirty beach. This spectacular spot is ruined by unsympathetic development and a filthy beach. I wouldn't let my children paddle in the sea because of the dead seals and floating dog poo. (And that was before we saw the warning signs about contaminated water!) Unruly dogs and their aggressive owners make a walk on the littered beach a frightening experience for children. Modern houses are being built on the beach, almost at the high water mark. The once-quaint harbour is full of decaying sinister hulks. This is a disappointing place that has missed a gooden opportunity.
Great view and ice cream. Free parking, clean beach and clean cold water and the ice cream van, great for an afternoon's chill out. Not to mention the grat scenery around the bay

quaint fishing town. the quaint little fishing town has grown up but still has the fishing town experiencelots on offer to see and eat and off course being the fishing town a trip to hout bay would be incomplete if one did not eat fish.the drive to hout bay along the coast line is fantastic with unparallelled sea views and many camera opportunities the atmosphere in hout bay is beautiful and if you arelucky enough to be there on a sunday take advantage of the art and crafts markets and the fantastic food on offer

Lovely. If you are coming from or are going to do the Chapmans Peak drive, you definitely want to consider this a stop over. At the foot of the mountain and right next to the beach is the Mariner's Wharf restaurant, highly recommended, maybe a bit pricey but worth it, the fish is delicious!

A day out in Houtbay. This time round's visit to Houtbay included visiting World of Birds as well as Mariner's Wharf Grill restaurant.It was amazing, althought the weather was a bit on the dreary side I preferred this with all the walking we did. The atmosphere is great, there was a marimba band playing on the pier while we were having lunch that just made the day extra special. We ended up walking through the market and getting some gelato at one of the shops in the surrounds. Definetly a must do day-outing

Hout Bay!. This is a little gem, hidden away from the busy city. The road over Constantia Nek is rather narrow and slow during peak hours, but if you have the time it is very pretty. The other road along the coast is lovely and the one over Chapmans Peak has great scenic views! In the town area there are numerous little places to eat, and at the harbour there are also various eating places. If one drives right to the end of the road there is Snoekies and On the Rocks, which are both very popular and serve really super fish and chips. A sea trip to Seal Island is also great, providing the weather behaves itself. The red tour buses are coming and going about every 20 minutes or so, so one can jump on and off wherever you like!

Run down. The blue bus tour drops you off here and it was a bit disappointing, there was an antique shop selling nautical ephemera, very pricy - and a café. A short walk round the building brought you to a marina where a market was held but it was packing up at 12.30. I wanted to go to seal island on the glass bottomed boat but the boat was in for servicing and the few shops there were very lacklustre and sold the usual tourist tat. The beach was accessible but it had been a showery day and it was not somewhere you would want to stay and relax. The views were lovely over the bay however and I am sure on a sunny day it would have been a better visit.
Lunch in Houtbay. Very nice town to spend some time shopping and enjoying the restaurants and sight seeing. If you love the sea you can take a boat out to seal island.

Beautiful Bay. We stopped here before embarking on the trip to Cape Point and the Chapman Peak Drive. Great little harbour with what seemed like a leisure marina on one side and a working fishing port on the other. We visited on a Friday morning and thee was a fair size craft market on the quay side, full of the usual carved wood, ceramics, Ostrich Eggs etc., but interesting for all that. As we drove out, we could see the magnificent beach, but clearly wind may be a problem on windy days as sand was blown across roads and some bushes etc were almost buried.
Beautiful bay. Travelling along the coast road we stopped at this beautiful bay to take in the breathtaking scenery...a must
Yum! Yum! Fish in Hout bay.. Loved the high mountain drive to get to Hout Bay! Loved the fish. My American husband says it's the best lobster he has ever eaten.

Make a trip to Mariner's Wharf. A beautiful little place nestled between the mountains. Friendly people and good service all around. Take a trip through the town and then go to Mariners Wharf and have a bite to eat

A Gorgeous Setting. After driving across Chapman's Peak we saw this awe inspiring view. We stopped at Mariner's Wharf for some amazing sea food and a drink as the sun went down. We returned to the beach the next day and just hung out and enjoyed the sun and the sights. The parking lot was a little difficult to find due to construction but we turned off the GPS and we were fine.We had lunch at Dunes Beach Restaurant. The food was good but the service was slow (not that we were in a rush)

lovely fishing harbour. Good food to be had here, unusual shops and a beautiful beach. Watch seals playing in the harbour. There is also an excellent craft market over the weekend. *****fish and chips
Not to be missed. Amazing views, with good sea food at Mariners wharf. Do not miss the photo opportunities. The Flea market and the local crowd add to the quaintness .

A picture perfect bay. Hout Bay which is near Cape Town is the point from where one can take a boat trip to see the seals. The antique and handicrafts for sale by the locals as well as having a fish and chips at the restaurant are two things not to be missed.

Charming. Hout Bay has developed so much these past years, great market on the weekends by the harbour, great restaurants available with Kitima for an amazing thai food experience, Massimo' for great pizzas, Ragafellows for divine burgers. Chapman's Peak drive with its breath-taking view! For the kids world of birds, where you can walk into a cage with little monkeys coming on your shoulders... A great family and friends place! And if you're into hiking, there are some great spots too!
Pretty. Hout Bay is a pretty beach with nice restaurants. It is more quiet than many of the other popular beaches and is worth a visit.

Lovely beach, boring place. Only thing to recommend Hout Bay is its proximity to Chapman's Peak.The Saturday and Sunday markets are fun, but the population is mainly made up of retirees from all corners of the world. Not a place I would like to live in.
Great time!. You must visit, the food is excellent as is the scenery, keep your eyes out for seals if you are into photography, they make excellent subjects!
We gone there to buy seafood. A quite good experience to go there to buy seafood for our diner!! We bought lobster and scallops!!! Too cheap and toooooo good

The Friendly bay. This is a beautiful harbour town, twenty minutes outside Cape Town. It has a beautiful coastal road on either side with plenty lookout points and picnic spots. The harbour has a big selection of restaurants and from fish and chips to fine dining. On weekends the Hout Bay market is not to be missed, there are some seriously skillful talent living in this coastal town.
