Another must do is a trip to seal Island, there are many boats leaving the harbour hourly. Hout Bay is also home to the World of birds, the largest bird sanctuary in the world, also worth a visit. This is definitely a town of character and worth exploring…
Mariners Wharf Restaurant & around Hout Bay. Good seafood restaurant, lots of eateries and shopping stalls in the harbour. Prices are fairly good.

Overrated in the extreme. Overrated suburb of Cape Town, full of overpriced restaurants. Local sense of entitlement is huge and attitude to outsiders is generally poor. Dirty beach offers nothing except E.coli and smell of fish from local processing plant. Why would you come here?

Hout Bay. Hout Bay is a tourist attraction, in my opinion a little to much hype and not enough byte. Yes it is a fishing "village" (you will be able to tell by the smell), maybe a bit more industrial due to the factories. The Bay itself does not offer much as a destination.. yes you will have some photo opertunaties of some trawlers, mabe a stray seal in the water and there are a number of small formal curio shops, coffee and eateries / watering holes available plus the informal curio vendors that sell the all too often repeated "African" curios and the typical "made in china" stuff you can find almost anywhere in the Cape. Hout Bay should be experienced by boat, get on a ferry or book a sunset cruse from Hout Bay via seal island, Llandudno, (Sandy Bay), Clifton to the V&A. The boats take you past seal island, beware of the smell... If you take a sunset cruse, then do make arrangements for someone to collect you at the V&A unless you are already staying there, or just grab a cab back home.

What a beautiful town. Visited the World of Birds then had a late lunch at the Mariners Wharf where we had fish and chips. The fish was crispy and fresh and the atmosphere was that of being on a boat watching the beautiful sea and mountain and the fog slowly rapping itself around the mountains, we had such a great time and will most definitely visit Hout Bay again!

Perfect weekend drive. Walks along the beach, the best fish and chips in Cape Town and Saturday afternoon Flea markets. The views of the ocean and harbor's are are beautiful and calming. Locals and tourists both enjoy everything Hout Bay has to offer. Love this place!

Great beaches, places to eat and scenic drives. I would recommend Fish and Chips at the harbour, take your paper wrapped meal and enjoy it on Chapmans Peak drive with a great view of the ocean. Katima is a fantastic Thai restaurant. The beach is lovely and there are loads of hikes starting from Chapmans Peak Drive.

We stayed in Hout Bay. We stayed in Hout Bay for the duration of our trip. I recommend staying there only if you plan on renting a car. We came from a country that drives on the other side of the road and felt uncomfortable renting a car there. It is very had to get a taxi within Hout Bay (most come from downtown). The hop on and hop off line has limited service to Hout Bay. It is a great place for a day trip. The seal tours are amazing. There is also a man who has rescued a number of seals in the area and the seals have now become really friendly as a result. The food is cheaper in Hout Bay than downtown and the service is excellent. We really enjoyed the Lookout and in particular the sauce they have. Hout Bay is a lot of fun during the day, but becomes very quiet at night.
So so. I would say Hout bay is sort of average comparing with other places nearby. However; if you drive, I would suggest you that the view along the way is beautiful.
Love it. Love the marine life in Hout bay. Such a beautiful place and very friendly people. Definitely an excellent choice for summer outings.

Mariners ' Dream. First of all the drive to Hout's bay is one of the most exquisitively picturesque experiences.We travelled the Chapman's route .Ended up in this quaint town bypassed it and went towards the Marina's wharf.Purchased tickets to watch seals at Duikker island and,mermerised ourselves watching these amazing creatures having a whale of a time basking on boulders and sprinting the seas.On dry land again and time for a hot cup of cocoa but we drifted into an antique shop rich with history and courtesy .Then we sauntered upstairs and discovered this wonderful restaurant called the Mariner's Wharf where the freshest of food was served by a bevy of sailors .So good was the restaurant that we drove each evening to have dinner there.Boulder' s beach is nearby if. penguins are in your book of fun.They were delightful to watch.
Beautiful Place. Had dinner in Hout Bay on our first day in ZA. Pretty place on the water. A must see on your way up and down Chapman's Peak.

Great old fashioned fishing village. Great example of old fashioned fishing village just outside Capetown.Complete with fish market stunning views shops & cafes & huge sea lions that keep leaping out of the water to delight the crowds!

A hidden treasure. The drive to Hout Bay from whichever of the roads that lead to it is stunning. One has the best of both worlds with the magnificent mountain ranges on one side and the sea to the other. The dock has retained its character and hopefully it will stay that way. This is still my all time favourite venue to enjoy a leisurely afternoon and a scrumptious sea food meal
Beautiful fishing village. On a Sunday morning I drove into Hout Bay and enjoyed it tremendously. The harbour is very nice with colourful fishing boats and Seals right there on the ward

seals everywhere. place is dirty with lot of hawkers. you need to have bargain skills to shop over there. there are beggars also. so be careful about pickpocket. there were plenty of seals. but personally i dont like them and find creepy.
Interesting. make sure you go during the lunch hour rush otherwise not much is happening and everything is closed

a Working Port. Travel here from the main Myciti bus station at the Civic Center where you can purchase your travel card for 35 rand and top it up with say 50 rand. The journey along the coast on the 108 via Camps Bay takes about three quarters of an hour and costs less than 10 rand. The 109 bus only goes into Hout town not the fish docks, so if you catch this you will have to change to the 108 at some point. Sunday's are busy with lots of people going down there for Sunday lunch. I had a pint of Prawns, my wife Moules Marinier, both excellent value for money. You can take a boat trip from here to seal Island and view Adams peak. Take a walk around the docks and watch the seals at play, one was tossing a large fish around before deciding to eat it. A couple of local guys were feeding the seals fish and for a small fee would show you how agile these creatures are when there is a free feed available, reaching almost full length out of the water for a scrap of fish.

Lovely little bay. Drive along the stunning Atlantic Coast Road and you come to Hout bay. Its a very pretty fishing village, with a lovely beach and harbour. There are a few interesting shops and a really nice elevated restaurant where you can spend time just enjoying a spot of lunch or just watch the world go by. A great place to people watch. Worth a visit.

Fantastic. We visited Hout Bay and immediately wanted to relocate there...Stunning views, laid back way of life...Every picture is beautiful. The food at the upstairs restaurant is brilliant, try the lobster and seafood platter for R500 or so, worth every cent! Also very reasonable prices curio and gift shops
Beautiful Drive. Hout Bay is a very cosy little town we drove through to go to Chapmans Peak, and was a beautiful drive up!!

Make sure to see Seal Island. Hout Bay has a nice rustic feel. The trip to Seal Island was great. Our group took a small boat through some very choppy water. The boat ride was rocky but fun. The trip to Seal Island around 15-20 minutes. Seal Island had hundreds of seals and the boat gets fairly close. Lots of picture taking opportunities.

World of Birds in Hout Bay = Wildlife sanctuary and Monkey Park. This is a HARD LUCK story turned into a miracle! We went to Hout Bay which has become pretty dirty, rubbish from the townships etc. I saw an advert for the birdpark and we spent several hours there. I do not want to spoil it for any traveller It is a great Park for all unwanted Bird Pets and Monkeys, that become a liability to families.

Taking a boat trip. Now this is just another experience. This place is stunning. You take a boat trip which is quite an experience. The beauty is watching the guys catch fish and then preparing it fresh out of the ocean for you to eat. The place is just something else. There is no words to explain the beauty. Always taking people to Houtbay

The Republic of Houtbay. This is one of the most beautiful harbour cities in the world. Houtbay has several great restaurants (brilliant seafood) and offers a wide variety of activities (visit the harbour, do a drive around Chapman's Peak or just go for a walk on the beach). When visiting the Westren Cape, then you can't miss Houtbay.

Fur Seals. Great to see seals in their natural habitat. The water was very choppy when we boarded. The boat has life saving equipment, but with water that choppy, I would think it would have been wiser to wear the life vests before the ship sailed out of the bay. You'll also have a great view of "The Sentinel" the rocky cliff guarding the bay. The seals are also very playful. Swimming around the boat as it passes through.

Nice Stop. Nice stop for souvenirs and to see the ocean. Prices for "stuff" comparable to the Green Market. If you don't have time to visit the green market this will do in a pinch. Make sure you negotiate.

Pretty Barbour. Pretty harbour where you can sit on the pier and watch the fisherman feed the seals, do some souvenir shopping, or get some seafood. Beautiful scenic drive to get to Hout Bay along Chapmans Drive, or stop there as part of the Red Bus Tour blue line

Calm water, rough seas. Took the Hout Bay boat trip to Seal Island with a group of Vantage World Travel. It was a kick. Calm water in the bay, and some dicey waves before entering the protected water behind the island. Lots of seals, beautiful scenery, nice weather. I recommend this if you're on the west side of the Cape Peninsula. Across the peninsula is another Seal Island where the great white sharks roam, but I had no desire to see sharks, much less with seals in the jaws.

Nice place for a couple of hours. Nice little fishing village, with the main highlight being the opportunity to take a boat out to see a nearby island with plenty of seals.Plenty of restaurants nearby, so a good spot for a couple of hours.Hout Bay is one of the stops on the sightseeing tour buses around town, so nice and easy to get to.

Lovely part of the Cape. Hout bay has a lovely beach area near the harbour with fantastic views of the surrounding mountains. Go for a day to the beach, take in the beauty of the landscape and go for a lovely fish meal at the Mariners Warf restaurant. Try avoid windy days as it'll blow you off your feet.

Fisherman's Wharf in the Republic of Hout Bay. A visit to the busy Hout Bay harbor and the Fisherman's Wharf Restaurant brought back many good memories of my childhood and the dingy hanging in the foyer helped my wife to see what we had gone to sea in all those many years ago, The food was good. The beer better! And we bought some fantastic mementoes to take home with us. A must for every visitor to Cape Town
Always good to be there. The drive to hout bay is scenic so passengers are never bored.Once there you have a choice of restuarants and places of interest to visit.

Catch a boat to see the sea lions. Safe, short boat trip to see sea lions resting on boulders in the middle of the sea. You gave a range of boats at different prices. A few tame sea lions jump onto the peer to pose for a pic. Beautiful creatures

I Love Hout Bay.... I visit Hout Bay at least once a month. Even if it's just to sit on the side of Chapmans Peak to watch time go by.Hout Bay is the start (or finish if you like) of the magnificent Chapman's Peak drive. Plenty of places to eat and also make a turn at the Harbor. Go and see how they feed the seals and how tame they are. A trip to Hout Bay would not be complete without a stop at Snoekies (fish and chips).Hout Bay is also home to the World of Birds.And don't forget, it is the Republic of Hout Bay :)
Hout Bay. Is deffinate a place for a Family day out. Hout Bay, for me is a place worth going to for the day. With sea food take out or sit down and boat trips for sea lovers. Worth spending on

Spot the dogs. Hout Bay doesn't have a massive beach but it is definitely a lovely one to spend an hour at in the mornings. Many people take their dogs to play in the water and on weekends there are also families with small children who play in the shallow water, digging sand and building castles.

Scenic and sunny. Hout Bay is a suburban paradise, situated between mountain and sea. The beach, particularly the side closest to the mountain, is sandy with easy and safe swimming. Restaurants abound - an old favourite is Chapman' Peak Hotel restaurant, another is Deli Delish. There are two markets - one on the green near the Hout Bay Hotel, which is not as good as it used to be, and one down at the harbour - which is vibey, fun and funky. There are some interesting and quirky shops along the main road leading to Chapman's Peak.For Capetonians, Hout Bay is a fun day out, an easy getaway in the city, with wonderful natural and scenic beauty. For tourists, the markets are worth exploring, the beach is very good and the scenic drive over Chapman's Peak is breathtaking - one of Cape Town's "must do's".

Nice and casual. White sand beach and sea lions every where in the harbour... no need to take a boat to go and see any!A fish market and a line of old souvenir shops that make the place quite fun to visit, but it doesn't take much than 30min to see it all.The ride is nice along the seaside and enjoyable.

A pleasant tourist trap in the old fishing harbour.. The old Hout Bay harbour is home for whalewatching trips and visits to watch penguins. But visiting in winter most boats were laid up. But a typical tourist market can be found here on Thursdays, and if you must buy some tourist tat to being home, her is as good a pace as any.

Rough and rundown. We came to Hout Bay looking for something to eat after a wonderful morning at world of birds as we arrrived we where greeted by unclean looking restraints and cafe's and the goods at the market looked tacky and unauthentic save yourself time just go further along to camps bay after a day of exploring the cape but world of birds in well worth a visit!

Worth a visit.. Visited September 2011.Not much of a popular tourist attraction which I liked. Had a nice market selling various things to buy as souvenirs. We took a boat ride round to see hundreds of seals! The sound they made were fantastic. We also saw a few whales as it was mating season.

A fun market with outstanding an food selection. Hout Bay Market rocks. We needed a change as we usually visit the Biscuit Mill. I loved the fact that it wasn't over-crowded and that on the day we went there was ample seating for our group. The food selection was superb - from my favourite Kudu biltong from Namibia to a spicy Thai soup at 10.30am to an almond croissant to hot chocolate with marshmallows. For my next visit I'd like to sample the smoked salmon and the crayfish. The broad selection of available food would satisfy the most demanding palate. My daughter loves the nachos which did look very moreish, and the fresh coffee also looked very tempting. The market is under cover which is a huge bonus for the Cape weather and is open on Friday nights and Saturdays and Sundays. I liked the fact that there was room to walk and browse and ample parking. Biscuit Mill by comparison is always a long walk from wherever one finds parking

Fish and Chips. I went with my family that live in Cape Town to visit Hout Bay and Have a delicious fish and chips lunch. We had a good wander around and looked at the craft that they have there. Have brought a reminder home from there to New Zealand a lovely wood craving of Africa which now has pride of place in my dining room. The lunch was superb very fresh fish and we all enjoyed it. The children had a great time as well. Well worth a visit

Hout Baai Worth the trip, for the view!. The setting of Hout baai is unparalleled, though I found the Hout baai market a little pretentious and the seafood at the harbour overpriced and unexceptional. Dunes Restaurant on Beach Rd more than made up for my experience at the Harbour though.The beach also has wonderful views but was dirty!

Great place for fish and chips!. Been there many times before and its definitely worth going. At the harbour you will find the fishermen having their own live seal show happening. They will charge if you want to have your picture taken.Also check out the restaurants around there and try the fish and chips. Cape Town traditional food. The views are breath taking. And if you are in for more of an adventure make sure to check out seal island!!

Definitely worth checking out. A great little town to take a day out and enjoy the drive. Many things to see such as the Bay Harbour Market, DARG animal shelter and the harbour itself, which has a tame seal that you can feed.

This is a MUST to visit when in Cape Town. I visited the lovely indoor market, huge variety of goods on sale, but lovely to walk through and browse too. Such a big variety of food on offer too, but I couldn't resist the temptation to pop across the road to Snookies and eat there!

Pretty beach, and very cold water!!!. Friend of us told if u came to Cape Town u should tried the water.. so, they force us to take off the shoes to walk on the beach, and play with the salt water a bit. then u can tell every one I have being Cape Town...haha. that is fun.. nice beach.. even in winter, u can get the truth view for the 12 follows mountain view too.
Beautiful little place. Only passing through on a day tour... But the fish and chips were great!!!Pretty little place and worthy of a couple of hours if you are touring the Cape.

Overated Do not have high expectations. Vastly overatedThe commercial aspect in some parts is intrusiveThe bird park is definitely worth a visitFor a reason I do not fully understand the sense of fishing village is lostSouvinere shops are tacky and scream commercial let us cash in on tourists

a little of everything. hout bay is a great little suburb easy reached by bus from cape town if you don't have transport. it's big enough to offer a few shopping malls, some good restaurants and a nice beach. so it could be a good day trip for anyone who wants to get out of cape town for a day. last time i was there i happened to sit next to jackie chan, the chinese movie star, in a restaurant in the harbour.
Do the Great White shark dive!. It is awesome!!! It is well worth the time and money if you are going to be in SA during the winter months (our summer months.)

Fishing Village Experience. this is what makes the Cape so great, within 20 minutes from central town one can escape to a fishing village and get completely lost in the moment. First, the drive from Cape Town is most scenic as you amber long the coast over a hilltop to get into the Republic of Hout Bay. A stop at Mariner's wharf is a must for good olde fashion fish and chips. Buy and ice cream and one can walk around the pier looking at the fishing trawlers and people feeding seals while appreciating the view of Chapmans Peak. If your timing is right, you can witness fish being offloaded from the fishing trawlers. Photos are a must. A drive to the canons is interesting and a drive to the nearby beach is worth the while. Dunes, an Italian restaurant on the beach is both scenic and offers good food. great place to laze a lunch with kids.
Brilliant . One of the most relaxing places. The mountain ranges make for some fantastic views. The walk on the beach here is so wonderful. If you have time make it a point to go. You won't regret it

Hout bay harbour. This place is beautiful, the beach and the harbour have so much character and the people have so much flair. We were entertained by one of the locals and a seal. Make sure that you buy some fresh snoek from trawlers before 12 noon if you are planning on making your own lunch or try Marines Wharf Restaurant or walk to the market, with lots of fabulous food stalls and crafty knick knacks. Overall a wonderful morning and afternoon spent in Hout bay.

The bay is beautiful, seal tour is alright, deals from vendors were the best.. This was one of our stops of the Cape of Good Hope tour. The fee to take the boat tour to "seal island" was only about $5, which is definitely worth it. But in general, in my opinion, it was nothing super amazing so if you are short on time you could skip this activity, but once again the price is too cheap to pass up as it is still a neat experience. If you get motion sick you may want to take something just before as the combination of the rocking boat (depending on waters) and stink seal crap may turn your stomach.At the pier where all the seal tours depart there will be a bunch of vendors selling neat African souvenirs. I found that the prices here were the most reasonable when compared to anywhere else I had been on my South African tour, so if you're needing gifts buy them here! Then, if you can, take the drive up Chapman's Pass to get a stunning view of the bay. There is a great lookout point to snap some great photos!
Houtbay. Quite little town. On route to Chapmanspiek with awesome views. Nice boat trips in harbour. Whale watching in season

Great Town!. Wow....lots to do as at the sea..always fresh fish. lots of seals in the water. Fantastic seafood places to eat at. Harbour tours and beach. Town not far from beach area. Bird santuary & Monkey world close

Seal Island at Hout Bay. Pleasant though choppy boat trip. Lots of seals when we reached the island. Make sure that you have good grip if sitting outside, otherwise for the squeamish stay inside the boat. there's a glass floor to view the bottom of the sea.

A 3D postcard. Hout bay and all its picturesque glory was everything and more in person. I expected a nice outing but was completely blown away by the rolling mountains, blue water and snow white sea gulls on the horizon. This is probably the one place I would consistently visit when in Capetown. I highly recommend a visit to this serene and beautiful place.

I love Hout Bay and surrounds. No visit to Capetown is complete without a visit to Hout Bay. Gorgeous white sands and stunning blue waters. You can get some great fish and chips and some good shopping with quality African craft wares available. If you are looking to buy some fresh fish this is the place also, with fishing boats bringing fresh fish straight to the Bay Fish shop. A really charming place with a relaxing vibe.

a must place to visit in Cape Town. Hout bay is a must place to visit in Cape Town, with nice beach for kids to play around, nice restaurants, and great experience to go to Seal Island by boat, really easy to hop on into the boat, not too expensive, seeing beautiful scenery along the way..

Hout Bay. If you're visiting Hout Bay be sure to visit the Hout Bay Market! Located at the end of Harbour Road the market is filled with traditional and modern African crafts, vintage clothes, and a wide variety of food. The market often has live music and always has a great vibe!

Cozy little town. Take a day trip from Cape Town, you can even enjoy the beach of Muizeberg on the way. You can get there by car, or f.ex. the metro. Go to the restaurant by the peer, or sit at the book cafe. Plenty of options for a small town trip out of CT

Seals paradise. Here you can stop for a cup of coffee and refreshments. You can also visit the seal island with a boat. The tour takes about 20-30 minutes, it not expensive and definitly worth it. There is LOTS of seals out on that island. There is also lots of sharks out there, didn't see any on my tour however. In the harbor there is a man who, if you buy him some sardines, can feed some seals and let them do tricks. He is easy to recognize since he looks like a pirate. There is also a marketplace for handcraft.

Very far away and nothing to see or eat. The place is not so close to Cape Town: I was advised to go there by a local who recommended the food and views, but I couldn't find anything different from a fish and chips place next to the docks. Nothing special. The drive from CT to Hout Bay is impressive though.
Lovely. One road in, one road out. Beautiful. Ocean. Mountains.Sky.Seals at the harbour.Sand dunes covering the abandoned cop shop.

Nice seaside place. I and my friends did stop here on our way to Cape of Good Hope, when one couple wanted to visit the seals out to a small island. We other strolled around and took a coffee and bought some nice handicraft from the marketplaces in the harbor.

Beautiful. These beaches and homes are beyond words. The water is absolutely gorgeous. Life styles of the rich and famous for sure. A lot of movie stars own homes in this area. Outside of town about 20 minutes.
Hout bay. Our favourite place to stay in SA it was our second visit and we will be back.good places to eat and drink and easy access to Cape Town

Unassuming, relaxing. This bay is quite different from the rest of Cape Town. It's much more laid back. Has a very unassuming character. It is more like a fishing village. Take a walk along the harbor, enjoy some snoek here.
Nice Bay with the best ice cream. Nice bay with a really nice market on friday's evening and the best ice cream i'ver ever had at "sinnfull ice cream". Perfect after a day trip to Cape Point.
Fabulous Snoek. Great views and fish and chips to die for!! Spent a very enjoyable hour there as part of a Peninsula Tour.

Blinding Fish & Chips!. Being from the south coast of the UK I know good fish and chips when I have them! The snook here is recommended as is the hake. The seafood selection is worth a shout too although abit expensive for what you get.
Beautiful. Beautiful town wonderful views, superb fish and chips in this, has a lovely relaxed atmosphere, great little markets and is wonderful seeing the seals swim freely in the harbour
Sandy and Sleepy Town. Seems to be the hub for Hippies and Bohemians alike. Colorful with the pungent smell of fish in the air and sand in your nostrils.

Seal Island. Went to beautiful Hout Bay to go to Seal Island. Went in the afternoon to avoid the crowds. Enjoyed the boat ride to the island and saw so many seals it was almost difficult to photograph them. We didn't see any sharks hunting them - not necessarily a bad thing. This isn't a long boat ride so it was an enjoyable stop on our sighteseeing day.

Double Charge Operator. I booked for Friday and Saturday night and was unable to turn up due to last minute commitments. On the Saturday morning I recieved a email asking if I was going to use the room for the Saturday night because if not they had other people wanting to rent the room. I quickly replied that I wasn't going to turn up so they could rent to room to the other people wanting to stay. A few days later I see they charged me for the second night even though they charged someone else to stay in the room. I think it is quite unethical to charge for the same room twice for the same night.

Do the 1 hour boat trip. We called in to Hout Bay on our Cape Point tour. Did the boat rife out to see the South African fur seals - number varies from 600 - 5,000. Not sure how many there were on the day, but we had plenty of time to watch them play around. Price ZAR55 each.

A Jewel in the crown of the Western Cape. We visit Hout Bay every year and are never disappointed with the area. Superb beaches and harbour where this year we took a trip out to seal island. Fish and chips is the best choice for a lunch in a host of eateries close to the sea. The busy and lively atmosphere, along with the friendliness of the people make Hout Bay a "must visit" every year.

Mind-blowing Magnificence. We drove the spectacular Chapmans Peak Drive and as we turned one of the many sharp bends, Hout Bay opened up before us, revealing itself more and more the closer we got to the Bay. It is truly magnificent with a natural beauty that reduces you to speechlessness. We thoroughly enjoyed an amble around the harbour, spotted several seals, and to top off our afternoon, indulged in strawberries and GnT on the beach :D This is unmissable!

Great place to visit. Things to Do in Hout Bay1. Fisherman's Warf - best Snoek and chips or Hake and Chips on that side of cape town. A must try when you are in cape town, the queue can be long so don't go midday during the holidays when you are starving ( up to 1 hour+ wait).on the other side of the seaboard is Kalk Bay which serve the next best Fish and Chips in Cape Town, so when you are going to or from Simon's Town and passing Kalk Bay, Stop at the fish and Chips shop there, there are two, go to the one that is close to the entrance and closest to where the fishing boats unload There will be a lady there that screams out the orders. You won't regret having some of the best fish and chips ever.2. Seal Island. There are hourly cruises to seal island which takes you close to the seals, there are some others tours around that you can do but this is the most popular one. 3. World of birds, in Hout Bay but not close to the sea. A awesome place if you want to see a range of wild birds and even spend some personal time with some monkeys. 4. The Beach , cold water, not the ideal for swimming or sun bathing but okay to walk and wonder about.5. The Hout Bay shops for local foods/curios6. If you fancy some live lobster that you might want to take back to your place and create your own fusion, drop me an email and I will let you know where to go to get 2kg of live lobsters from a factory in the area. Legal. Tax invoice and all. It will cost about R500 (rand) for 2kg which equates to about 8-10 lobsters in a box. You can buy one cooked lobster at fisherman's wharf for R160 so it is a no brainer not to buy fresh live lobsters unless you don’t know how to cook it. I don't check my tripadvisor email that often, so if you don't hear from me don't despair or try emailing me at devtcomm @ yahoo . com
nice spot. nice place to spend an afternoon, not much here, but a few shops and places to eat, nice to get out of CT and see the sea, clean beach.

Nice for a Visit, perhaps some Sushi. But rather don't live here, unless you want to get turned into Shashimi by one of the local criminals. With a burglary rate about double that of Woodstock (Hout Bay averages over 600 burglaries a year), Hout Bay has become a bit of a war zone, thanks to it having its own steady supply of impoverished criminals that live on just up on the hill, in a sprawling, densely-packed shanty town. Chaps with knives and weapons might well just pop through your window late at night. So, unless you're a bit of a Rambo or have dogs the size of small male lions - just stop over for the day.
Very pretty. Worth a walk around but do it in the early morning before the fish market really gets going - can be a bit smelly on the wharf!

Fantastic Beach. A beautiful ( but can be windy) sandy beach which swings round to the fishing harbour is backed by a small town of neat houses. From the harbour you can take a boat out to visit the Seal colony. For a very good lunch find the Dunes on the beach. Superb fresh fish and great service.

Nice Stop on Peninsula Drive. Nice stop on our Cape Peninsula Drive via Chapman's Peak cliffside passes carved out of the mountainside along the Atlantic seaboard. The whitesand beaches seem to have lots of tourist and locals with their dogs. We ate a restaurant overlooking the bay, a nice stop on a fabulous drive.

dont miss the "hout bay museum"!. its a must! once u are in cape town, you will (and if u dont, u have to ) pass by the hout bay at least once. its very pretty and has a history (check out the hout bay museum)

Pretty fishing village. This is a stop on the Hop On Hop Off bus. Very pretty village especially with the fishing boats in port. Nice beach where a lot of locals go. A nice place to while away some time in the sun.

Only a short visit but very enjoyable. I stopped off at Hout Bay on my Cape drive so it was only a short visit and just around the harbour area. None the less it was a lovely scene with the bay enclosed by mountains, colourful fishing vessels and the famous Chapmans Peak Drive hugging the mountain side across the bay. The beach was clean and provided plenty of room for all pursuits from football to kite flying or just a lovely, relaxing walk. Well worth it even if it's just for an hour.
LOVE HOUT BAY. we enjoyed shopping for african crafts are the post area...this was the cheapest area to shop for souvenirs plus the coffee shop beside the lighthouse had good coffee,,,

Best Place To Stay When visiting The Cape. Location location location!It is perfectly situated for access to Chapmans Peak, Cape Point, Cape Town only 20mins, Camps Bay, Clifton, Constantia etc etc but also its a good beach for waking & a plethora of safe eating establishments you are spoiled for choice.Ideal base for exploring Western Cape.

Seals. We made a stop in Hout's Bay only to be able to take the ferry to Seal Island. It's a 30 min ferry ride and you get to see a lot of seals. Very nice! There were some high waves on our visit and the crew were good enough to inform us where the life vests where and repeatedly encouraged us to hold on, switch sides to avoid water from the waves and so on. Very good (and, sadly, unusual) to get this sort of information on a tourist boat!

Worth a couple of hours or more. Hout Bay is a cool town with a nice harbor. The beach isn't spectacular so go to Camps Bay or other places for lying in the sun. However, the harbor is the main attraction with many fishing boats and the opportunity for having fresh fish and chips. My wife really enjoyed her food at one of the local places. We did take the 45 minute trip by boat to Seal Island. I would rate this activity very high and would recommend it. The cost was around $4 per person. We enjoyed our afternoon at Haut Bay
lovely drive with a scenic view. a nice scenic drive and in the town a must to eat at the famous FISH ON THE ROCKS. the fish is tasty, fresh and with quick service.

Good picture opportunities. If you go for the Chapman´s peak drive you will go around this bay anyway but it is just another good argument to do the trip. I strongly recommend driving the peak driv up to North so you can have spledid picture opportunity and also have a wonderful view down to the water. There also is a wonderful beach but bathing is only for those who like their water cold, 16 Celsius is about the best it gets.

popular public beach but water too cold. in the good old days the hout bay beach was whites only beach, but these days you can't see the sun cause of the...no, just kiddin, very nice and clean beach, and public transport makes it easy to get, only problem is that the water are too cold , need to be a capetownian to bare them, quite a shock for someone who hopped in from a vacation near the warm mediteranean sea, hence the water are not so crowded, people can't stay in them for hours like they use to do in warmer waters, the sand is very clean and the view, also on the mountain side, is great, several restaurants along the beach, public toilet and showers are hard to find, but than again, you are at the big blue ocean.

Great stopover for a walk. This was another stop on our bus tour and we took advantage of having a break and a brisk walk by the sea until the next tour bus came by.It is a small place but with a charm of its own.We re-visited when we collected our car so we could spend some extra time and have a drink.
Fifteen Minutes to a slice of heaven. Hout Bay is a beautiful town. The beach is great for a stroll and the sunsets are beautiful over the mountain. Plus, it's right next to Chapman's Peak drive !

I love this place. This is my favourite spot near Cape Town. Beach active harbour lovely seafood and superb views.Sitting at Marinas Wharf with a beer and a smoked snok sandwich looking across the bay and the beach looking at the Chapmans Peak Drive must be one of the best views in South Africa. A must see spot

Nice seaside location, well located for exploring the Cape. We stayed in a very nice guesthouse (Amblewood) overlooking the bay. Hout Bay is well lcoated for gettign to Cape Town - particularly Table Mountain - and exploring Chapman's Peak and the Cape. A boat trip to Seal Island is recommended. The restaurants we visited (Fishermans Wharf and Pescadore) were so-so but nothing special. Stunning scenic views along the coast in each direction. OK for a base to explore the Cape, but I wouldn't want to spend too much time there.

Traditional fishing village. Lots of fresh fish to be had in the bars and restaurants. A very busy family resort next to the harbour selling authentic African crafts. Best bit - watching the resident seal sunbathing on its back with its flippers in the air!

Over the Hill to a wonderful spot. Lovely seaside "village" in stunning setting. Plnty to restaurants whether just for a quick coffee or a full dinner. Working fishing harbour. Visit a huge colony of Cape fur Seals on nearby seal Island; travel over Chapman's Peak to scenic Noordhoek or drive through the Constantia winelands & do some wine tasting......

working harbour. A working harbour in a perfect bay - large fishing vessels and docks - tours can be booked. A large curio market and several stores and places to eat along the docks. Seals all over the harbour. Snoekies famous for fish and chips. Ample parking.

Excellent place to stay. Third visit to Cape Town area, second time that we stay in Hout bay.
Definitely I prefer to stay there then in Town.
We rented a House just in front of the ocean, close to the dunes restaurant.
Wonderful is the word to use!

Loved trip to seal island. Loved loved loved the seal island !!!
Use nauticat charters as there boats are well structured !
Also going to seal island was a memorable trip. Lovely scenery and seals !

Seal Snorkeling!. Great experience to take an inflatable out to Duiker Island and get a chance to snorkel with Cape Seals! Water is a frigid 10 degree Celsius, but the wet suits keep you warm. We got to snorkel for 45 minutes and the up close and personal interaction with this colony of 15,000 seals was a phenomenal experience the entire family loved! Very memorable experience!

Fish and Chips a must when in Hout Bay. Hout Bay harbour is "famous" for fish and chips and there are a number of restaurants that meet the demand. Public holidays can find the place packed and long queues for food or restaurant tables, but the harbour ambiance makes the wait worth while. There is a safe beach next door to the harbour where one can go for walks or the kids can play, or just take a walk and explore or buy a ticket for a boat trip to see the seals.

Remarkable Views Over Clear Water & Mountain Range. Perfect viewing area on the road to Cape Point. Very surreal views and amazing coloured ocean. Offers a fantastic beach as well as many more activities.
Gorgeous Bay!. Past Camps Bay & on the way to Cape Point on a spectacular coast road, Hout Bay has a fantastic white beach, a fishing fleet & you can take a boat to see a seal colony.

Culture Lifestyle at it's Best. We took a Boat Ride to Seal Island well worth the Drive.Very Beautiful Beaches Excellent Places to eat from Fine Dining to Casual.Try the Snook & Chips.You can also purchase lots of Crafts on the Pier

Hout Bay contrast to V & A Marina. Nice to see fishing boats here. A vast contrast to sail boats berthed at V & A Marina. There was a local lady and her "performing" seal posing for photo-taking tourist, another local guy demanded a fee for taking photo of "his seal" ! There is a lovely restaurant.

Go for the Markets. There is not a whole lot to do in Hout Bay but if you time your visit then it is a great day out. Head over on a Friday evening, Saturday or Sunday for the Hout Bay Market. Great goods, entertainment and lots of good fresh food.
Fish and Chips on the beach . You must go to the fish and chips restaurant. Enjoy a capetown staple beside the white sand beaches. The locals love it and so will you

Visit to Seal Island!. Hout Bay is on the route to Cape Point from Cape Town city. When in Hout Bay, travellers must surely get on the boat to Seal Island. It's not that I've never seen seals but to see so many of them in their natural environment is an opportunity one shouldn't ever miss. The ferry ride by itself is pretty enjoyable. On return, the passengers are greeted by a group of musician / singers with painted faces and colourful clothing. You could tip them if you so wish!
Great fishing community. Really good seafood, friendly folk! This is a must stop for anyone visiting near Cape Town. The Blue line from Hop on -Hop off bus goes there. Nice views of the bay.

Bit sandy. Went there on a day it was very windy and chilly. There is a lot of sand around, being blown around, not the most comfortable thing. The town itself, not sure, did not get a very good feeling about it I am afraid.

I don['t understand.... We were so excited to visit Houts Bay. We went there on the hop on hop off bus and when we got there.. there was nothing really to do. Yes, the beach is beautiful... and yes there was a lady feeding seals but there were no shops to wander around in and nothing really to do. I think you need to go there when the markets are happening (Friday nights and Sunday) otherwise don't waste you time.

A nice stopover. You may pass Hout Bay on your way to Cape Point but it is definitely worth a look around. To me it is a cross between Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco and a down to earth working port. Some parts are looking like they could do with a makeover. There are numerous trips you can go on like catching a boat to Dulker Island and see the seals. I liked just wandering around and taking photos as it is that kind of place. There are numerous souvenir stalls along the front and an ATM in the middle next to a snack bar. I think a day is plenty unless using it as a base for exploring further afield.

Amazing seal viewing. We went to Hout Bay as part of a day trip from Cape Town to the Cape of Good Hope. Our tour guide stopped at the wharf so we could go on a boat trip in the bay to view seals.Fortunately, we were a few minutes late for the first boat that was about to leave - it was packed to the rafters with tour groups. The next boat along the wharf was not booked out and so we had no trouble getting a seat on the upper deck.While waiting for it to depart, we took photos of a seal being fed by a man sitting on the wharf near the boat. This was nothing compared with what we would see later. The boat sailed out of the bay to a group of rocks where there were dozens of seals sunning themselves on the rocks and swimming in the water nearby.It seemed as though the various boats were timed to allow one boat at a time. Our boat pulled up very close the rocks in the surging waves and winds to allow us to take as many photos as we liked.We were there for about 15 minutes before the next boat arrived. Because there weren't many other passengers, we were able to move around during that time to get the best shots - hanging onto railings as we went to make sure we stayed on board rather than joining the seals in the water. The whole expedition took almost an hour.It was a beautiful sunny day and so we were able to enjoy the fabulous views of the bay and the coastline as well as the seal viewing. It is beautiful setting.There was plenty of activity at the wharf including entertainers who welcomed each returning boat.

Charming seaside village. Hout Bay is a seaside village reached by a 25 minutes drive along the scenic coastline from Camp Bay . Attractions in the town include The World Of Birds , Chapmans Peak drive , Mariners Wharf which is busy over the weekends and well known with the locals for it's fresh fish & chips . There is a nice beach that you can walk on and also boat trips out to Seal island where you can view Cape Fur Seals . Circe launches offers the cheapest tickets and they all go to the same island . Hout Bay is best visited when it is not windy . Best views of the town from Chapmans peak drive and also a great place to watch the sunset from .

charming. nice friendly town, next to the wonderfull Cape-Town and our last discovery Camp Bay; has all the things you might need on holiday: nice restaurants (you should try Marine-Warf!), some supermarkets (main-stream is very good, and the bakery inside mains-stream is the best!), an African cultur market on sundays, a gas-station etc. The only thing I wouldn't advice is going to world of birds (very very poor animallife if you ask me)

Day or night - must visit Mariner's Wharf. Busy quay to walk down and watch the fishing boats bring in the latest catch. Safe parking on the beach and delicious meal and tasty coffee at the restaurant
lovely place. great views and a working fishing port with great beach - good seafood restaurants and on blue route for red buses..

Awesome Views, Lots of fun, Great for Shopping. Cheapest place in all of CapeTown to buy sovieners and gifts for friends. Very well priced and negotiable as well makes it a win-win. Stay for a few hours if possible and take the ferry to see SEAL ISLAND -- it is AWESOME! well worth the time especially as part of a peninsula tour. There is an ATM as well which is the best way to get cash if you are not from South Africa to bypass all the transaction fees. This is the cheapest place in CapeTown to get Ostrich Eggs - buy them for around 90rand each which is $9 US.
Miles of clear Blue Waters. Brilliant place. A long scenic drive leads to Houts Bay & once you reach there its sheer bliss for the eyes with miles of clear blue waters. A place to chill

Sleepy fishing village with charm. If you are a critter lover, you will want to add fur seals to your list of animal sightings on your visit to SA. Here you can buy a ticket for a short boat ride to Seal Island. This open air boat ride offers scenic views of this bay and beyond. On a clear day the wind is brisk, sun wonderfully warm and you will see numerous sun bathing and swimming seals. You will hear them as well as smell them! On occasion, I have heard you might even witness a shark feasting on these unlucky bathers. I saw no such thing, anyhow it is a nice outing for terrific snapshots and video. The little village has an ample assortment of souveniers at reasonable prices and eating establishments that are quite good. Easy to find a cold drink and relax here. Nice and charming people trying to make a living, so enjoy.

Hout Bay with cruise to Seal Island. The cruise to Hout Bay was pictureous. The main attraction was the Seal Island. All the Seals were sitting and sun bathing around. Some were splashing away in the water enjoying themselves. They smelt awful - all fishy. It was great seeing the Seals.

Quaint. Hout Bay is a quaint fishing village that is friendly and has a great vibe about it. We were with a tour guide that brought us to Snookie's restaurant for Fish and Chips and it was incredible. Be aware it is not easy to find behind the docks but the locals are more than aware of it and it is popular for good reason!
moreSAplease. Nice beach, if a bit busy in the holidays, with interesting local history, and loads of semi tame fur seals. A couple of good restaurants and a good atmosphere.
Good for one visit. If you love sea food and want enjoy a relaxing lunch then hour bay is the place. Plus if you want to see Seals then you can get on to a ferry that will take you to seal island

Friday night - Hout Bay market - Don't miss it. Live music, cold beer, warm fire, great wine - Why would you not be here. There is a variety of stunning food stalls where you purchase your meal and all sit together enjoying the company of friends at a table. The clothing stalls are fantastic. There is something for everyone from young children to older people. Highly recommended.

Do Not Miss This Enclave. Cape Town is obviously beautiful but Hout Bay is a gem! Nestled in the mountains it is just absolutely gorgeous. A very cool vibe in the community, Very convenient to Cape Town, about 25 mins by car.

Visiting Seal Island?. As part of our full day Cape Peninsula tour, we stopped for the boat trip to Seal Island. Admittedly, it was not a very nice day - a little overcast and rainy. The cost is about 5 USD. The boat takes about 5-10 minutes in each direction (you don't leave the boat), but if the weather is not perfect, it passes through some very rough water. Rough water = seasickness. I am not prone to seasickness, but this boat trip did make me sick (and others as well). I think the guide, if not the boat operator, should have been more cognizant of the water conditions before sending us off. Leaving a rocky boat and then travelling in a van on a bumpy, winding road caused me to spend the next 4 hours in major discomfort.If the weather is good and you never get to see seals, it may be worth the trip - I wouldn't go otherwise.

Seals everwhere!. We enjoyed the trip to see the seals and the area. Great place to see them in their habitat. Also, a beautiful bay between Cape Town and Cape Point. As well as beautiful drive along Chapman's Peak.

Beautiful town,Excellent and vibrant harbour area. Tipical fisherman's town,beautiful beach.Affordable boat trips,lots of souvenir shops and stalls,very good restaurants and at the foot of the famous Chapmans peak.
Something fishy. Definetly the place to go for some fresh fish. Anything fresher is still swimmimg, is their motto. You also get to share in teh experince of fishermen, and go on a bat ride.
Go see the seals people!. I didn't see much of the town but did go out to seal island where there were hundreds of seals lounging. Definitely a good way to start the morning

New discovery in Houtbay. We discovered a new venue packed with traders,music and amazing food stalls. Drive to the back of the harbour (only one road that gets you there) Follow the road past Mariners Wharf and enter this wonderland. We were very impressed.

Beautiful Bay. Another great stop on the way from Cape Town to Cape Point. This spot is really beautiful. There's a place to stop where a lot of crafts people display their wares... and don't miss the guy who has a trained seal that will do some great tricks for you... remember to tip the trainer. Any guide will know this spot.

Slight disappointment. Was expecting a relaxed and easy boat ride to see the seals, but unfortunately the ocean was so rough and the boat so unstable that both me and wife were quite sea sick!! Fortunately the photos taken from our shaky vantage point turned out to be great (don't know we managed it though) and the day wasn't completely wasted. Would not recommend this though....

Picturesque stop on motor tour around the Peninsula. There are quite a few harbour restaurants here plus boat trips are available.The beach is also popular but the water on this side is colder and it tends to be windier. On a nice day it is very popular. People also like to walk on the beach as well as round the harbour where there are lots of fishing boats. In the village there are often open markets plus the usual restaurants and art galleries etc.
'Hout' of this world. Hout Bay - my fave place to stay in Cape Town.Restaurants, bars, cafes, beach, craft market.....gateway to Chapman's Peak - it's got the lot !!!

Supreme bay next to Cape Town. Good option to consider rather than an accommodation in Cape Town itself. It is indeed not far from Cape Town (15 minutes by car), but it's a different bay offering a more relaxing atmosphere than the city centre of Cape Town. It is also the perfect gateway to access the other villages in the Southern tip of the Cape region and to visit the Cape of Good Hope. The only weak spot is catering/restaurants, which is diverse but average.
lots to do. There are markets, beaches, shops.It is a very scenic drive.Hout Bay market is where you can purchase african art,clothing etc.

Disappointing. Hout Bay is a stop for the hop-on hop-off bus and we planned to have lunch and spend a couple of hours there. After 15 mins we decided to catch the next bus out . This area has the potential to be a great tourist attraction but unfortunately it is nothing more than a dingy fishing port. The restaurants in the harbour are lack-lustre and the public toilets a disgrace. There are nicer areas of Hout Bay with good restaurants but these are some distance from the bus stop so if you're planning to go there, go by car and give the harbour a miss.

Treating the family. What is better than taking the family for lunch on a Sunday at Mariner's Wharf - and taking a stroll afterwards on the harbour and weather permitting, taking a boat ride to Seal Island. take the glass bottom one!

Expensive....!!!!. I wanted to take my girlfriend out for lunch in Hout Bay, Needless to say every restaurant we walked into was very expensive. They cater only for tourists and not for the Locals at all. The area and scenery is worth the drive though.

Give it a miss. We stopped off at Hout Bay as it was on the city sight seeing tour bus route. There was not much there and the shops/restaurants were a bit tacky. We had a walk on the beach and then got back on the next bus when it arrived

Lovely :). Nice stroll around the markets, coffee at a nearby coffee shop and then onto a boat to go snorkeling with seals. Pretty magical!! There's also a fat seal just behind the market stalls which this man feeds and gets you to pay him for a photograph with the huuuge seal. He even puts fish in his mouth and feeds him from there.. interesting to say the least.

California Coast???. You could be fooled into thinking you are on the California coast as the beaches, houses and ocean look similar. The mountains though burst the bubble! And the ocean is the Atlantic. But the buzz and the bustle are similar too!

Lovely Gem In The Cape!!!. This is a very beautiful part of Cape Town, far from the madding crowd of the Cape Town CBD, the V & A Waterfront and the big shopping malls. The scenic mountain and sea views off Chapmans Peak Drive make it so out of this world. The lovely beaches along the shoreline all the way from the Cape Peninsula, to Kommetjie up through the Hout Bay area including the Llandudno, Chapmans Peak, up to Camps Bay all the way to the V & A Waterfron in Cape Town CBD are sandy and relaxing.The Hout Bay Harbour is also an interesting place to visit.There are lots of excellent conventional and boutique hotels, as well as restaurants that give good value for money in this area. I always thought I knew Cape Town until I spent a great deal of time in this part of Cape Town.Lots of friendly lovely people. We will always make time to visit and stay in this gem of an area. It is ideal to hire a car when visiting this area.
Eat Fish & Chips. Do yourself a favour and come here to have fish & chips while sitting on the deck watching the world go by. Really well the travel from CT

Vibrant little settlement. Arriving from a drive around the coast, Hout Bay is a lovely little spot not too distant from downtown Cape Town. The day I visited was pretty windy and overcast but nevertheless it was a pleasant place to visit.We were passing through on our tour to Cape Point so didn't stay for long. Just popped out to Seal Island and we were gone again. The wharf area is pretty alive with all sorts of activities.

Quaint little town. I visited Hout Bay on 19th May 2013; where I found flea markets on a Sunday, food fairs on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. The beach was amazing and crossing Chapmans Peak on foot and by car was very exhilarating.

You must visit The Hout Bay Market. We spent a lazy morning at Hout Bay Market. Arriving for breakfast which was good value for money followed by excellent cappuchinos. A leisurely walk around the market proved to be a real eye opener. I was expecting a flea market type set up but found quite the opposite there was a huge variety of stalls including food / coffee & cake. Plus areas where you could get a beer / glass of wine. Stallholders were really friendly all in all a really nice half days entertainment. We will definitely be going back - Often !!

Go to the Hout Bay Food Market. A great day out- i love this part of the world. Walk along the harbour- taking in all the sites. and head to the Food Market for something special. Divine atmosphere and really delicious things on offer. Friday nights are always a blast. Otherwise Saturday and Sunday day.

Scenic route. We took a boat ride to see seals! The boat ride is just awesome! The mountain and seals are beautiful! This place is a must for any nature lover!There is a domesticated seal near boating area, it is nice to have a closer look!There was music and dance on streets! Lot of energy and it lifts up the whole scene!!

Don't miss the seals!. A quaint fishing harbor with charm! We stopped on our tour of the Cape Town coast line and are so glad we did. The 45 minute boat ride to see the seals was well worth the cost if you are a nature lover. Real 'candy' for the eyes!

One of the most beautiful places around the Cape. Llandudno and Hout Bay are spots that we appreciated a lot. The beaches are just super! Be aware that sharks are everywhere, and that the water is freezing could, but Llandudno and Hout Bay are gorgeous for a walk on the beach and a view on the fantastic villas.

Best fish and chips. If you are in Hout Bay you HAVE to stop at Snoekies and get their fish n chips, it is the best in Cape Town and you must eat it on the beach and share with the seagulls, great experience.
Wonderful little town. With its own little fishing harbour and charter boat services you cant go wrong. Lots of restaurants and pubs and the lovely Chapmans Peak known for the Argus Cycle tour.
Bit over rated. Depending on what you are used to I felt this place was over rated. I dare say even a little reminiscent of 80's south of Spain.. but with over priced underserviced facilities.

Hout Bay. Good: Hout Bay is for those who dont like being in the centre of a large city and prefer more of a village/small town ambiance. It is a delightful little place, and has a very good little shopping mall with an excellent woolworths (same as UK M&S) and other small shops including a homeopathic store and pharmacy. The harbour offers lots of interest too, with regular boat trips out to sea. The locals are friendly and there are two excellent markets a week. One craft market on the green on sundays which is a delight, and the bay harbour enclosed market which offers a wealth of foodie delights and some colourful if not slightly overpriced stalls. But all in all Hout bay is a must. Would definately prefer to stay there than in central capetown but you have to have a car!!!

Perfect spot. A pleasant town, perfect for exploring the area. A good selection of restaurants and shops and excellent Saturday market nearby. Quieter than Cape Town and within easy reach of Kirstenbosch and other local attractions.
Hout Bay Rocks. We love Hout Bay. The Beaches, the laid back attitude, Out of town but still central. Only one little dislike was sometimes the smell from the canning factory

I love the Republic of Hout Bay. The best way to enter Houtbay is via Chapman's Peak from the Noordhoek side towards Cape Town. Amazing views! Go for FIsh and Chips at Mariner's Wharf - a local institution for fine fish :) Take a short boat-trip to Seal island for some more amazing views and end it off with a soft serve ice cream when you get back. 2 Nice markets on Sundays

fantastic. fantastic beach didn't stop but had a great view from the open top red bus,lots of people jogging playing ball or just relaxing the cafes and bars where well buzzing,but unfortunately didn't have time to stop wish I had though still cant do it all !!

The Republic, still worth a visit.. You cannot beat the entrance roads to this place, when it comes to beauty. If you travel via Chapmans Peak from Kommetjie and Noordhoek, then you are in for a treat...but there is a toll fee. Coming from Camps Bay, you will have awesome sea views...stop at the lookout over Llandudno at sunset for a special view.A walk along the Hout Bay beach on a nice day is always worth it and this can lead you straight to the harbour attractions if you wish. Should you prefer to join the locals rather, then coffee (and breakfast if you are hungry) at Darios on Victoria Rd is the way to go.A lazy lunch or dinner at Dunes on the beach is rewarding on a beautiful day and many foreign tourists do this very thing. An Italian restaurant, called Luigis, frequented by the locals is very popular. One drawback? Getting behind a heavy truck or overladen taxi going up Constantia Nek! Takes forever at 20 kms an hour. Also, cockroach taxis (Toyota Conquest etc...) stopping wherever they like, holding up traffic and making a nuisance of themselves. A bit more thought for fellow road users would be in order.

sooooo freshhhhh. Hout bay is an amazing place. The fresh fish and prawns served at the cafe's were yummy!!!!! the natural beauty of the place is calming to the soul.the seagulls were quite hospitable and the boat ride is refreshing.the local guy and his seal "show" was a novel experience.all people visiting the Cape must add hout bay to their itineary
A nice bay away from Capetown city. We stayed overnight with friends who have a beautiful villa overlooking the bay. A pleasurable stay with visits to nice restaurants and a stroll along the bay.

Taste the cheaper seafood. Try out the Lobster and chips here, nice taste. Much better and much cheaper than the crayfish of sushi restaurant in Camps Bay.There are local guys and kids asking for money from you. There will be guys feeding seals and ask you for some money. Be prepared.

Secret Take Aways. People always go to the restaurants that well marketed and easy to find. There is a "Take Aways" in a container that has the best toasted bacon egg and cheese!Just walk past the Mariners Wharf and you will find it on your left hand side! Enjoy!

Hout Bay. There is much to see and do in Hout Bay. On entering Hout Bay, Suikerbossie, a lovely restaurant, greets you. It is on the left side of the road, nestled in the mountain. It offers delicious meals, including devine afternoon tea. Driving along the road into Hout Bay, near the World of Biords is La Cucina, a delicious restaurant. The harbour offers much to see and do and over the weekend, a fabulous market. Take a drive to Hout Bay and you will certainly find something to eat and see.

Disappointing. Hout Bay - not much too see, no restaurant to be found where one can just have coffee. The scenic route WITH toll ....! was unforgettable! Must admit - I didn't venture into town, I wanted to be at the harbour and enjoy the sight without consuming alcohol.

Nostalgic visit to Hout Bay. Hout Bay is a pleasant seaside town near Cape Town. Having stayed there in the past I visited on a Sunday morning when the market on the Green and the Concert in the small ampitheatre in the Shopping Arcade are usually on. The latter had no performance on this visit but the market and town were delightful. The return via Constansia after going via the coast road made the trip even more enjoyable.

Beautiful view. Visited Hout Bay as part of a stop on our Peninsula tour, and it was lovely. Great views of the bay, with occasional areas along the road where you can stop to take photos. There is a section of the road you need to pay (to maintain the road). The actual harbor view is also nice and you can see some seals even without going on the boats. There are lots of stalls of african handicrafts and it was a great place for me to get photos without feeling too pressured by the sellers. I think most people go there for the seal boat trips, and not sure what else there is to do there, but definitely stop to enjoy the views OF the bay from the road on your way in/out.

Beautiful. Very good seafood restaurants. There's amazing views of the harbour and surrounding mountains. The drive there is good to with nice views along the way. Lots to do and see. Boat trips are worth your while!!!
Fun side trip. Hout Bay, known as the jumping-off point to see the seals lounging on rocks in the ocean, is also beautiful by itself. It might have been nice to spend an afternoon there.

Hout Bay, Cape Town. Sand everywhere, what used to be estate agents offices - now covered with sand (you can see the roof of one office !) There's a very strong smell of fish in the air. B&B's with notice boards "park at own risk" ...

stunning. Hout Bay was stunning, we took a boat ride around to where the Seals all chill. There was hundreds of them on the rock and swimming around us. The scenery was amazing, it didnt feel real! After the boat ride we drove round the bay up onto the top and the view was just breathtaking!

Beautiful area - great restaurants. We visited Hout Bay twice from 2 different vantage points. An evening and afternoon encounter.The first one was our first full evening in SA. We went for dinner at the Harbor House. The food was amazing-fish just off the boats that day-4 daily specials with excellent sauces and fresh veg.The next time was for a late afternoon lunch at Dunes. We had been to Ambeloui for a champagne tour and took our delish champagne to this outdoor cafe on the dunes. Enjoyed great sunshine, blue skies and a quick walk into the very cold water.
hout bay. great views... quiet restfull good position for travelling around cape town and outlying districts not hapy aboutpaying for parking at harbour
fab beach. great cafe and beach. Nice multicultural atmosphere unlioke some of the predominantly white resorts further north

A Quiet Harbor Town and a nice Seal Island. The boat to the seal island leaves from a quiet harbor, where you are welcomed by someone who feeds seals as he holds a fish in his mouth and a small band that plays when the boat leaves and returns. There are many seals on the island, waiting for their picture to be taken. Upon return to the harbor you can see a castle on the slope of the mountain, as rumor wants it, a copy of one in Liechtenstein built by someone for his lover.

Improving all the time!. Hout Bay has counted itself as removed physically and mentally from Cape Town for ever! This gets more true every year, as the facilities in this quiet little town improve year by year. It has good restaurants and hotels, a couple of fun bars, and some good photo opportunities (look for the houses being swallowed by the dunes, as well as the leopard...)Know to get windy & chilly very quickly though!
Beautiful drive. It's a beautiful drive to get here from Cape Town. Downside is there is a lot of sand in the streets and the air as the wind blows constantly.
Cosmopolitan. Love this place full of shops, markets, artisan food and fabulous beach. There are delicious restaurants to choose from and great mountain walks

Loved it. I strongly suggest that every visitor to Cape Town goes to Fish On the Rocks at the very end of the Hout Bay Harbour Road and has their Snoek and Chips. Pay the extra 50c for a plate, and enjoy. The view down there is also spectacular.
beautiful and icy water!. the sunwashed beach drew us to the water. We rolled up our pants and dipped our toes into the iciest waters we've tried (and we have a house in Canada!)

Seaside Village Vibe!. We visited this lovely seaside town and it was bursting with a holiday vibe that was so welcoming. The long white sandy beach was quite full as the weather was particularly good. There were many people swimming and really enjoying the splendour of the beach.As I think most do, we ate at the Fisherman's Wharf. The fish was super fresh, and although we had to stand in line it was well worth the wait. Seating outside was at a premium, but the turn around time was quick and we sat and enjoyed our meal to the life sounds of a African Marimba band playing on the quay side.After lunch we took a stroll around the harbour, sight seeing some of teh local fishing boats and local shops and was amazed as there was this local coloured chap that was feeding the wild seal, and even did a couple of holding it in his mouth and the seal rose out of the water to take the fish straight form his mouth. It was entertaining.Nice place to visit and really feel you have found a piece of beauty!
Picture Perfect. We took a boat to seal Island. They were just Magical.It was a perfect day for Seal watching. A band of singers welcomed us back to the dock.
What a view from Chapmans Peak. Stopped at Chapmans Peak on our tour of the Cape thanks to our guide. We took a lot of time to take photos and capture in our minds the wonderful vista before us.
Beautiful. Houtbay is very beautiful. The drive from Cape Town is very scenic. Try the fish and chips at the restaurant on the waterfront, their cocktails are good too!
A gem. A stunning town to just be in. The beach was fun, and the view from Chapman's Peak will take your breath away. The wharf is a tad touristy but we still loved it.

The harbour is the best bit, after the beach. We walked along the beach and into the harbour area. On impulse we took a boat ride out to Seal Islands. It was unlike any other seal islands we have seen, and we have seen lots in Scotland and the isles of Scilly. Very atmospheric.
Nice for the beach and sunset. We drove here every afternoon to see the sunset and take a walk on the beach and next time will consider stayin here as it is 10 mins from Cape Town
Great Views. The fantastic views of Hout Bay, especially from Chapmans Peak, never fail to impress. In the evening get yourself along to The Outlook Bar-Restaurant for great seafood (and ribs).

Best outside bar/restaurant in Hout Bay. "LOOK OUT " bar/restaurant in the harbour super place to relax sitting outside on decking with sun umbrella overlooking Hout Bay harbour . Clearly a special meeting place for locals .

The reality of political confusion. This is one of my favorite sites to visit. Snoekies restuarant is a true Cape Town experience, with possible boat trips, offering scenic views of the mountainous surroundings. However, the squatter invasion which shows the political indicision of local government is degrading the town and taking away the former glory and euphoria! But I still love to go there.

The Seals are so cute. Although it really stinks there, the cute seals compensate the foul odor. Actually, you will feel it in the bay (we could not eat there, as the odor was so terrible, so don't be hungry when you go, but don't eat right before going there either :-)). When you get on the boat and get into the open sea, there won't be any smell. And on and around the island you will have a smile on your face all the time. The seals are very playful, they live their life without looking at people. Do it if you have time!

A town with his own passport. Some years ago the inhabitants of hout bay (hout meaning wood) declared the city of Hout Bay a republic. Actually one of its inhabitants was admitted in Egypt with his Hout Bay republic made passport. Hilarious

Make the drive from Chapmans Peak. Cracking views of Hout Bay as you drive over and down - can get busy at weekends and closed during cycling events, but pick your time and head as the sun is setting and you can't go wrong. Pop into Mariners Wharf for a Lobster Platter while you're at it.

very nice place. This is a superb restaurant. I am recommending it with confidence.
The food was great. The music was nice and relaxing
Delightful beach. A great beach with a little shack boasting the best Fish & Chips which we would not argue with. Great clean long stretch of beach which is never busy everytime we go.

A scenic town away from the city. While in Cape Town it's worth going to the "otherside" of Table Mountain and visiting Hout Bay. It's a beautiful town surrounded by mountains and a beautiful bay. Eat fresh sea food at one of the restaurants at the old harbour of along the beach front.
Great View back over bay. Great View back over bay when heading towards Chapmans Drive. Photos a plenty but they dont do it justice

Pretty stop for shopping and food. We stopped for about an hour on Hout Bay. There are ample market stalls lining the small harbor. its a really nice location to take a break. Our guide took us around the corner to an indoor market that is a must stop. There are the usual african crafts but done better, clothing, food, and whatever else you can think of all in a hip, clean setting.

Beautifull. I love this place ,fabulous beach and working harbour ,it is never too busy as its away from Cape Town ,you can get the red bus from town out here .The fish restaurant is great and very reasonable.ive always found the market here cheaper than in town ,my favourite place around cape town .

Not seeing it. Don't quite understand what the fascination with Hout Bay is all about. It's a quite little fishing village with serene beach (at least on a weekday) with a bunch of not too appealing fish eateries, which, in their defence, I did not try. In the harbour: stands selling all the things your dust at home can't wait to settle on. Frankly, I can't wait for the bus to arrive to get away from here and back into the hustle and bustle of CT.

Make an effort to go here. This bay is over on the Atlantic Ocean, not right in Cape Town. Take the hop-on, hop-off bus over there and enjoy a few hours. Spectacular setting with lots of options for restaurants, shopping, etc.
Very Pretty, Loved the Seals. Went out on one the viewing boats to see the seals and it is impressive to see how many there are. Apparently it's a shark buffet at certain periods of the year.

Excellent sandy beach alongside working harbour. There are some good restaurants to explore as well as boats trips for fishing and sightseeing including glass bottom boats. Good all purpose beach although water is cold.

I lived in Hout Bay, Princess Street. The best place to mend a broken heart and then came back time and time again to enjoy the beautiful weather, beaches, restaurants, tranquility, cleanliness, quiet and charm. Incredible hikes and wooded walks. Heaven.

Too bad man. After driving down the superb Old Chapman pass ......
Where to go ????????
F
A stincky fish and fish without any interest.
A nice view for a restaurant like Tourist trap ... Not that nice to feel...
Too agresive for us. We're turning back.
We have been lost in the jungle of streets
Info ??? Where about ?

Good views, many restaurants.. Worth a visit as the drive with views are just out of this world. The drive is only about 30 minutes maximum from Cape Town, less from Sea Point. Worthwhile to visit the harbour, try the smoked snoek, or eat at one of the restaurants.Hout Bay itself is a small sleepy village, filled with restaurants serving all types of food. Worth a drive Of course from there one can continue to Chapmans Peak and Cape Point.

A must see when in Cape Town. HOUT BAY is known its magnificent mountains and sparkling blue sea views, its vibrant cosmopolitan restaurant life as well as its laidback “village” lifestyle.The drives around hout bay has the most awsome views . Chapman’s Peak Drive which overlooks the Sentinel Mountain across the bay is my favourite .I had a privlidge of watching a whale from here .There are many pleasure boats operating in the Hout Bay harbour for trips to the seal island and ship wreck .Tried quite hard looking for sharks on my trip but did not see any. Snoekis is my favourite resturant
hout bay. How can one not love Hout Bay. Went to the Beach and saw a beautiful Pittbull being filmed on a skate board... too funny

Hout Bay - World of Birds. Was just recntly in Hout Bay, Chappies is as always a wonderful experience, however the ocean at Hout Bay is ice cold, and polluted with a whole flotsam of plastic, we also saw a dead seal washed up on the waters edge. Hout Bay is still a great place to see the wonderful beach at Nordhoek, and to explore the Constantia winelands. A wonderful surprise was had at the World of Birds, reached by the Red Bus trip from Cape Town. Well worth a visit, for the birds, and for the monkeys :-)

Hout Bay. What a stunning valley, beach, wonderful resturants. Try the famous fish and chip shop at the end of the harbour. Also there is a wonderful new craft market which has opened opposite the chippy, open fri 4 till 9 p.m sat/sun. 10 till 4 p.m, wonderfully array of local crafts and fab food stalls,

Realistic Africa. I would describe Haut Bay as a more realistic experience of Africa. It's by no means a slum, but after the sterile environment of Cape Town, you are faced with stray dogs, unusual smells, boat fuel and market stalls. We went for the seal spotting, so grabbed a boat out of the harbour. I love a boat trip anyway, so it was nice to get out in to the sea breeze and across to the seal island, where we bobbed about for a bit while we all took pictures and tried to ignore the horrific fishy-seal-poo smell! Well, what do you expect?!

Good Base. Hout Bay is a good base for visiting Cape Town, the botanical gardens, Constantia for the wineries, and lots of other places of interest up and down the coast. Chapman's Peak Drive is spectacular stretch of coastal road and is a must do.There is a good choice of restaurants and a smal shopping mall in the Bay. The beach is white sand and popular with dog walkers. Take a boat trip to seal island a round trip of about 45 minutes. Visit the indoor market, open at weekends, at the end of the wharf. The Sunday market on the green is well worth a visit for gifts.

Great craft market on Sundays.. We always visit Hout Bay to stroll around the Sunday craft market and then along the beach. Parking can be a bit difficult near the beach but the areas surrounding the various shopping malls are secure and within walking distance of the beach.

My daughter's beautiful home town. The bay is surrounded by mountains, the sea is turquoise, the sand is white. There are several wonderful restaurants to choose from offering a range of international cuisine. Magic.

Quite Beach. Drive down Chapman's peak then comes this small and quite beach. The beach is picturisque and clean. Take a walk along the beach and can also take a dip in the waters! Off the beach a few cafes for beers and snacks where you can have a nice time. Its the beach you can see from chapman's peak is good! On both the sides of the beach are hills which is an amazing sight for your camera lens!

Hout Bay. Dissappointing - Littered and smelly. Especially if you walked to the end of the jetty. Beautiful from afar, but would give it a miss. Lots of people rate the fish and chips on Mariners Wharf, they sure smelled good but we opted to move on and eat elsewhere.
So pretty. We loved eating at the Mariner's restaurant in Hout Bay. The way the sea blends into the mountains is beautiful

Quaint Authentic Fishing Village.
