We hadn't been to about away for a long time and decided to go on our visit to Cape Town this time....so happy we did.Visited on a Sunday and as we're arrived at the end of the harbour, were met with many returning fishing vessels and their fresh catch....so colourful to watch & listen to the fishermen as they arrived.The market there is wonderful with superb fresh, typical Cape and other S. African delicacies to sample...great experience!

the bay of trees. will for ever shade you as you travel though this great bay, be sure to stop and enjoy the views go on the long hikes talk to the locals, both aquatic and terstrial ! also some nice pubs ;)
Lovely drive down Chapmans Peak,. Lovely drive down Chapmans Peak, lovely places to eat including a saturday market in a car park, chapmans calamari, mariners wharf. Worth a trip out of Cape Town

Will Come Back. A very beautiful place where it is good to come walk on the beach in the late afternoon before going to drink a beer or eat at one of many institutions. Not very far from Camps Bay by car on a super highway
what a briiliant place. absloutely brilliant , the views are to die for i used to like santorini and mykonos in greece but trust me cape town is far far far superior

Nice small community. Nice small village at about half an hour's drive from Cape Town. Neat houses and restaurants. Village is bordered on one side by mountains and on the other side by the ocean. Famous road to Chapman's Peak starts here.

Seal Island. Access to Seal island is at Hout Bay. It rained a bit during the ride, but the bay is beautiful and it was cool to see so many seals. There is a crafts market there, and you can also buy fresh fish there if you are near the area.

Visit to Hout Bay. We got taken round Hout Bay in a cab, and the scenery was spectacular. We stopped and looked around the wharf, but it was very windy, so we hurried back to the cab, On the way to Chapmans Peak, we were held up by filming being done on Hout Bay,A couple of days later we did the same thing on a Blue Bus Tour, and again saw spectacular scenery. We then went onto Sea Point and Green Point, finishing up at the Two Oceans Aquarium on the Waterfront.Gregory Chapman

My first visit to Cape Town. Hout Bay has some very nice restaurants. We visited for the day and took a boat ride which was out to see the seals. It was quite rough but a really nice way to see some of the coastline. Well worth a visit.

Best fish and chips ! :). Beautiful bay.Beautiful view.Don't miss to stop here to make a short walk and to eat the best fish and chips.You must wait,because usualy there are many peoples who want same think !:)And after you drink a beer,or two you could find in the shop near restaurant the passport for Hout Bay citizen.It cost only 10 ranzi !:)

Great place to start your Tour de Kaap. Hout Bay must have been hip, hot & happening in the sixties, it's not very interesting now, but you do find some good restaurants there, like Kitima (Asian food) and Luigi's (Italian food). We stayed at guesthouse/B&B Thandekayo, terrific place. Say hi to Banda for me!
Evening gettaway from the city centre. Great resturants, views and sunsets made this place a nice short gettaway from the town centre. Worth the short drive!

Super Seal watching. We stopped in Hout Bay for a short break on the way to Cape Point. We went on one of the cruises to Seal Island. Fortunately, the scenery is so breathtaking that even a boat full of really obnoxious screaming people seems unimportant (we were just a handful of folks that were not with one LARGE group). The boat certainly gets good,close views of the seals and turns around so both sides could see the cuties. We also took a ton of shots of the dramatic cliffs, clouds, and amazing water colors. The trip was well worth the small fee for the boat. Upon return, loads of folks from our boat stopped to enjoy the Cape Minstrels and the craft market, but if you are going around SA at all, you will see many markets with similar offerings.

Wow - Better than I expected. I must confess I visited Camps Bay and I thought "Fantastic" but on reflection I actually prefer Hout Bay, there seems more to do here and appears a nicer area. Plenty of hotels / bars / beach and close to many good attractions.

Great Place just outside Cape Town. Great place to stay if you need to be outside of the bustling city of Cape Town - only 20 minuets away and that was in heavy traffic, lots to do and on the door step to every where

Hout Bay. Disappointed to see that the local authority have decided to push the sand dunes back to espose the beach. The sand dunes are Hout Bay, so seems to have changed the whole look and feel of the place. Also felt that the area is very ethnic and felt a bit intimidated.

A Great Day Out. Hout Bay is a terrific place to spend a day (or longer). The markets are a draw-card with plenty of bargains to be had - must haggle though! All very bright and colourful. Fisherman's Wharf has arguably the best seafood on earth - grab the furthermost table from the front door for the best views, right in the corner. And try the King Clip (not hake!). The harbour is a hive of activity at the right time and there are plenty of great photo opportunities of the bay and surrounding mountains. The police station being swallowed by the sand dunes is worth a visit if not for the unusual spectacle of just that. And a photo of a young kid with the inadvisable penchant for feeding a seemingly semi-tamed but wild seal bits of fish from his mouth is a must, but he want some sort of remuneration (think I would too).
booring. just because there's a man feeding seals at the harbor I had an okay time.. If the day of your visit no boats are sailing off to the sea you will find yourself trapped on this boring bay
Seal Island a must!. Take a trip with drumbeat charters to visit seal island and then go have a cassata icecream across from them - wont regret it

A nice break on the way to Table Mountain Park. Hout Bay is worth stopping at on your way down to Cape Point. A visit to Mariners Wharf to see the daily catch in the fish market is interesting. The views from the other side of the bay are even nicer.

Haut Bay is very Beautiful. In haut Bay you can find lots of nice Views. it has a very nice weather in March and April. Its the place that you can take baots to Seal Island. There are lots of souvenir shops there where the prices are reasonable after Bargain!!!The peaks, the roads and the residents are all very good.Just try to visit there when you travel to cape town.

Flea-market. There is a brilliant market in the harbour that has an amazing selection of street food especially traditional south african cuisine. Also many african crafts, arts and other market items.
Lots to do there. Great for a day trip from Cape Town, lovely beach, lots of family restaurants, a most relaxing yet vibrant place, with realistic prices.

Hout Bay - a must. We had travelled the length and breadth of Cape Town and Hout Bay snuck itself into our hearts - it was so serene to watch the harbour - Snoekies to eat fish and chips is another must. It was a bit nippy and sadly we had to leave quickly as we were getting too cold and also was trying to make sunset on Signal Hill.
Beautiful place with vineyards. Lovely location and lots of wine estates you can stop at to sample lovely wines! Definitely worth the drive our of Cape Town!

Crowded but nice beach walk. Hout Bay is not far from centre of ape Town. It has loads of nice restaurants, though the Vida coffee shop near the beach was closed. We went on a public holiday, so should have expected the masses on the beach. But once past the crowds we had a lovely walk along the beach. The sea was too cold for swimming.

Interesting and spectacular. It was a busy day and there wasnt much room in ther car parks but we went to the market on the quay which was colourful and full of traditional souvenirs. we lunched at the Manor Hotel which was excellent and drove along the impressive coastal road via Chapmans peak. An enjoyable day out

once is enough. the Seal boat ride and watching the seals on seal Island is a nice experience. Not to be missed. The Catamaran ride is better. the Souvenir shoping here is average, nothing to rave about.

Fish on the Rocks. So much to do in this small little Town. The beach is excellent and the view towards Chapmans Peak to die for. The local community entices the "Robs" out of the water and photos are the taken of you feeding them fish. Can be a beautifull photo but beware....can also be very dangerous. Having a meal of Calamari/Fish and Chips sitting on the rocks, listning to the waves are just wonderfull. Fish are fresh and delicious.
Beautiful spot. We went through Hout Bay on our way to cape hope and boulders beach...it looked like a lovely spot where I would like to come back and spend more time.
The lobsters ... yum yum. Enjoy a platter for 2 at the Mariner's Wharf and make sure that you include the lobster option. Finger licking good. Good services, friendly staff and very popular.

Panoramic. Chapmans Peak drive into Hout or out of the Bay is one of the most scenic anywhere in the world and the Hout Bay area itself has so much to offer in terms of accommodation and eateries. Just have to visit Hout everytime we visit the wonderful Western Cape

Lovely fishing village. Houtbaai is just another beautiful little town in the Cape. A nice place to eat Fresh Seafood and see the Fisherman with their Catch of the day. You need only about an hour there.

As always, Hout Bay absolutely stunning!. The guy who feeds the seal from his mouth is a must-see! He has been feeding the seal for 32 years and the seal is 49 years old! What a great thing to see and experience!
Take the boat ride !. Great way to start your day : have a quick boat ride out to see the seals and see a different point of view of this lovely bay.
very nice. houtbaai is like a country fishing harbour with a stunning view and great lekkerbekkies and calamari @fish on the rocks!!!and take a nice picture from the restaurant upstairs

Bustling harbour area. With its spectacular setting and busy quayside, Hout Bay is a must on any Cape Town itinerary. Fish (of course) is the speciality in the popular, simple restaurants. Visit the African market and then head for lunch.

Plenty for the tourist to see. Boat trips and fishing trips are available from the docks, or you can sit and watch the seals being fed by the mouth of the locals....for a small optional fee of course! There are plenty of market stalls selling genuine African goods and a lovely restaurant which fills up quickly so reserve or get there early.

Stunning view.... The views here @ breath-taking. Quite a popular spot for decent fish and chips! Very friendly locals. Fish on the Rocks, very, very popular. Very speedy service. Beautiful scenery, whilst you enjoy your lunch!

Relaxing. Hout Bay is excellent if you are done with the city scene in Cape Town Central. Hout Bay offers a lovely beach for families and tourists, cape fur seals viewing (need to take a boat out) and a summer market with lots of goodies and foodies
Great drive through the mountains. And if you are looking for the best butcher's counter outside Cape Town then take a trip to Woolworths. Great helpful staff and braai meat to die for
Seal Island is a must. The seal island tour departing from Hout bay is a must. It was amazing seeing so many seals in their natural habitat. For lunch, Fish on the Rocks cafe was great.

Beautiful Houtbay. Very, very scenic, interesting market, nice fish&chips at Fish on the Rocks. Just have to be a very patient when it gets busy as the whole world wants to be there. Pleasant to shop in Mainstream shopping centre.
We came for the seals and were not disappointed. We drove from Capetown and went on the boat trip. well worth the price! We did not believe how many congragated on the small islands...
A pretty place to stay with easy access to all the key sights by car. A pretty place to stay with easy access to all the key sights by car. I stayed here for my entire Cape Town trip.
Beautiful and great fish 'n chips. The Bay is absolutely breath-taking and the harbour is quaint. The fish and chips at Mariner's Wharf were very yummy and were great value for money.

The Scenic Route. Taking a drive through Chapman's Peak will leave you in awe of the beauty and splendour of the nature that surrounds the beautiful Hout Bay area. You will be taken back by the abundance of colorful flora. The sea views will leave you wanting more. Take a slow drive and enjoy this area. Be sure to visit "Snoekies" for the most amazing snoek and chips or for more elegant dining enjoy the seafood on the docked off ship. You can complete the entire trip through Chapman's or you can pay to go up to a check point and turn back to the Hout Bay area. Don't be surprised when the teller refunds your money on receipt of your proof of payment. You will enjoy this are. Be sure not to miss it when you visit the Fairest Cape.

Busy, busy, busy. Beautiful waters and wonderful view from Chappies. Must take the boat trip to Seal Island. And off course the fish & chips is a must. Everyone has their own opinions about where the best fish & chips is sold. I say try all for your own satisfaction.
Boring nothing nice. overrated and not the best place for kids needs an upgrade same old thing year in and year out. needs to be more modern

A wonderful day trip!. If you are staying in Cape Town, take a drive to Hout Bay one day. The scenery on the way is gorgeous and when you get there you can have the most delicious fish and chips in the world! Save some time to visit the market too, where you will find interesting hand-made souvenirs.
10th Visit - As Exciting as the First. An amazing place reached by a beautiful drive - besure to take a bit of time and explore it - great place to people and tourist watch.

Don't bother visiting if its a windy day. Lovely beach. Average restaurants , saw a seal being fed by a man with raw fish in his mouth, other than that nothing to do of its too windy to sit on the beach.
Worth the trip!. Worth the trip up and down the whiny roads. Breathtaking scenery all round. Well worth the visit and toll fees.

Too many beggers. I visiited 15 years ago, since then shanty own has grown, we were accosted by beggers and hawkers alike and made to feel uncomfatable so we left for better areas of CHAPMANS DRIVE, SIMONS TOWN and the likes, too comercialised attracting the wrong kind of people to pry on tourists

Loved seeing the seals! Worth the 40 minute detour.... While driving down the coast from Cape Town to Cape Point, this is a nice little stop for a boat ride on smooth waters to see all of the seals on Seal Island!Our kids loved it, it's 40 minutes round trip & reasonably priced....cash only! Lots of little local handicraft stands at the wharf where you depart, too.

Not worth a visit any more. Sadly it seems that Hout Bay (at least the harbour) has set their eyes on foreign visitors - prices are criminal and th eplace is overcrowded. On our arrival there were at least 15 tour busses parked in the small harbour.We ended up going to the local Pick and Pay shopping centre for a meal as opposed to being ripped off for, what looked like, sub standard meals (judging from the overall impression of the various establishments)

Great views to Chapman's Peak. It's very touristic but with good reason - it has great views back towards Chapman's Peak (it costs 33 rand to come over Chapman's Peak one way). Mariner's Wharf is very touristic but actually the food was very good and the service friendly
Fishermans Harbour. This unique fishermans harbour includes a good restruant right on the water. Good food selection - just a bit noisy as a family restruant.!

Seafood Lovers paradise. Best place to get fresh seafood served exactly how you like it. Restaurant overlooks the harbour and if you are there and the wind isn't howling it is a nice walk around the bay
Mountains, Beauty, Food. I love the fact that there are a variety of food restaurants and shops. The view is amazing, the food proudly SA.

peaceful. staying in a villa at the moment and our view down to the bay is breathtaking. it is a quiet little town, lots of nice restaurants and pubs, a lot of british people, clean and neat love it here..

Back to reality. Cape town offers the best views which is the cnetre of attention. At Hout Bay, it was back to reality to see the kids play around freely and enjoying themselves. Hout Bay sells fresh fish and snoek and reasonable prices. The best fish i ate during my stay at the Cape, was at Hout Bay.
Tourist trap. There's nothing to see here. The fish and chips shop is mediocre, and there's just too many people crammed in here. Skip.
relax. Want to relax a bit in a smaller place, then drive the 15 min to Houtbay (Republic;-). Nice beach, nice restaurants and view of the bay is beautiful.

Fresher seafood u will not find.... Whilst here dont forget to take a meal at the Mariners Wharf. Be prepared to tow the line for an awesoe feast. The seal island is remarkable. We use the Calypso. More econoical and more fun than the pricier ferries,
Market. Loved the night market - chilled with a live band playing jazz and drank craft beer. Try the soup offered by Zoop - awsome.

gorgeous view - great calamari. the view as you come around Chapmans peak is breathtaking.
As usual both Dunes and Chapmans peak hotel were full up with Calamari lovers.

Very unique. We visited the harbour and took a walk around the area. Its a beautiful place which has an amazing restaurant that serves fresh seafood right on the shore. Another exciting thing to do is to go on one of the trips to Seal Island. The kids loved it!
Now this is a Bay. The area is scenic drama, steep rock surround fantastic drive around the bay and onto the Cape. Great stuff.

Beach, art and food. Hout Bay is an interesting old fishing village. There are still fish shops were you can buy a fabulous range of seafood at low prices and restaurants specialising in fish and seafood. The beach is very scenic and not so rough as Camps Bay as it is more protected. There are many fishing boats in the harbour. There is a good shopping centre including a Woolworths supermarket and some quirky shops and cafes. Also several art galleries and craft shops. In summer there is a craft market on weekends opposite the shopping centre with dozens of stalls. A good place to hunt for unusual souvenirs at good prices.

Beautiful views. The mountains drop dramatically straight into the sea, the bay is tranquil but the sea beyond is in keeping with the Cape of Storms. A magnificent place... There are some good restaurants and acceptable shopping, but you would not got to Hout Bay for the shopping - there are bigger and better Malls elsewhere on the peninsula. No, Hout Bay is about the beauty. So why just 3 stars? Well, some years ago, Hout Bay would have been 5 star, even 6 if that was an option. But today we have the scar of an ever growing squatter camp on the beautiful slopes of the Hangberg, and another across the valley, hemming in the once prime properties that cost their owners so much when they bought what they thought was a piece of paradise. And where there are squatters there is excrement, flowing accros the beach and into the beautiful bay. And there is crime. There is trouble in paradise...

sightseeing. Take the citybus tour, stop in hout bay for the market stalls and fab' food eateries. But make sure your next stop is Camps Bay, probably the best beach in Capetown, and stunning restaurants..
A Twee little village. In some ways, this is not exactly a tourist trap, so it is pleasant to stroll around the village. The locals who work on the boats are great characters to observe!

Save Time, Skip Hout Bay. Unless you are in the market to purchase a fishing boat (or perhaps a yacht), skip Hout Bay. There is no beach to speak of. It is depressingly dirty and down and out. Spend your beach time at Camp's Bay.

Worth a look. If you are driving take a trip here. It is where Chapmans Peak begins and this is a wonderfull drive with great scenery. There is a small toll to pay and there are lots of places to stop to take photos.

Beautiful!. This is a lovely place! Try to go on a warm sunny day as the beach is gorgeous.The day we went it was blowing a gale but we still enjoyed it.We can recommend the fish and chips at the harbour!

Interesting side trip. Our group stopped in Hout Bay to go to Seal Island. The catamaran ride over, then back, was relaxing. We had a beautiful sunny day to enjoy. Note: You look at the seals on the rocks, you do not get off the boat.
I prefer tours when you learn about the sight - not just see it.

great location. I have been to Hout Bay many times - and I always enjoyed the only fish restaurant there- but this time i felt the food was not good at all - as usual we ordered a fish platter - it came but was entirely covered in a creamy butter garlic sauce- baked over and browned - we had expected as previously that the sauce would come on the side - their claim they always serve it that way could not be accepted as we knew better - but still an interesting and good place to go - just make very very sure you get your food with all sauces at the side - otherwise you wont like it-

Houtbay paradise. I often visit Hout Bay, and always find something new and exciting. It is a true little gem, and not pricey at all. If you visit Cape Town, and not go to Hout Bay, you haven't see nothing yet.

Great. Houts Bay is a fishing area, interesting harbour to walk around, market and restaurants, watched the seals feeding and just swimming up to the edge to say hello, boat trips available to Seal Island well worth doing.

Sweet little harbour with tons of fun. Nice place to catch a few rays and while away a few hours. There are beaches with umbrella rentals and lots of places to shop and eat. Fun for the day or just a few hours.
Lovely!. Visited a good shop in car park and a resturant overlooking the sea for a drink.Views are beautiful.
Very nice. Small town on the sea shore. Only 20 mins from Cape Town so great for a half day out or to eat in the evening. Plenty of good resturants with good prices.

A piece of Paradise. Such a variety of things to do, from the World of Birds, a trip to Seal Island, and great seafood at Mariners Wharf.Our friends wowed about the fish and chips at "Fish on the Rocks". Unspoilt beaches and fantastic mountain views.
Nice roads, nice B & B's. not too many restaurant but nice sceneries, nice roads...go to Groot Constanta for dinner...Excellent

Seal Island. Hout Bay picturesque ans spotThe Sentinel rock. Coffee stop on way to the Cape. Souvenirs available. Seal Island trip fab but a bit scary with proximity of rocks and heavy swell. Minstrel band excellent on return from trip which is bout 45 mins. Have a few coins ready.
Quick Stop. It was raining the day we were there but it was a nice stop on the way to Cape Point. It is a bit more touristy then other points along the way
Excellent and close to the nature. Nice place to observe the sea lions on a small rocky island (one hour round trip). If the wheather is windy, the trip with the boat can be adventurous
Hout Bay. Hout Bay is absolutely beautiful. If travelling by car, make sure to go via Chapman's Peak the views are breathtaking and unforgetable.. You must try the fish and chips.

For the views. Make sure to visit the harbour and try the fish and chips! Then rent a car and travel via Chapman's Peak drive to Noordhoek. It'll probably take you an hour, because you will want to stop every five minutes to soak in the views.

Boat ride to seal island. I decided to take the boat ride to see the seals - big mistake! The sea looked calm from the shore but once we got further out into the bay it was Very Rough! There were plenty of seals and perhaps it was enjoyable for some people but definitely not for me!!

RICH DAD POOR DAD. You can see wealth and poverty living side by side, but that is not the attraction. Great fresh seafood at the Wharf / harbour and amazing views along Chapmans Peak Drive is unforgettable.

Beautiful, easy access to western cape. We stayed for 6 weeks. We could visit everything in the area in under 2 hours (drive) including whales in Hermanus, beaches Cape Point, awesome coastline south AND north towards Cape Town central. The Red Bus is a great way to get around. Hout Bay feels safe. Chapman's peak is a GORGEOUS drive ...so on and so on!

Lazy Days. What a picturesque little fishing harbour traditional fishing boats chugging in and out of the harbour watch them unload the Yellow Fin and watch the restauranteur's argue over the price watch the seals playing behind the boats waiting for the off cuts of fish then settle down for a nice bottle of wine and fish and chips very lazy but perfect
Cute fishing town. Great place to stop for some fish and chips in the harbour. Bonus were the seals playing near the docks. Great food and atmosphere, especially on a sunny Sunday afternoon.

Worth a visit... Wonderful views with mountains on one side & sea on the other..Loads of fishing trawlers around and seafood restaurants...The weather was really cold being winter in August, so we could not dare go for a swim to beach nearby...
A favourite. Watch seals in the harbour and fishing boats chugging in and out over a lazy bottle of wine and fine food. Another stop on the tourist bus blue route..........no need to drive.
DRIVE TRHOUGH. Mariner's warf restaurant is a gr8 experience and good sea food. make a booking before hand, to prevent waiting too long. The view form the popular lookout point is excellent!

Siikerbossie - Hout Bay. If you want a delicious breakfast on your way to Hout Baby proper, stop at Suikerbossie for fabulous service, food and a view that is breathtaking. Lunches are are great and afternoon tea and scones certainly takes a beating. Also a wonderful venue for weddings etc. Well worth a visit.
Nice bay. Very nice bay and example of fisherman port, also fish market. If you are lucky you can see some sea animals in the bay port.
Chapmans Chance. This village below Chapman's peak formerly named Chapman's Chance is a visitors pleasure with fish and chips from the harbour a must taste.

Take a trip to seal island. The seals are right there in the harbor, but take the one hour trip out to seal island. There are vendors selling all types of crafts there in the marina, but wait to buy things back in Cape Town.
Sea and sand. Love the sheltered beach. There is plenty to do - lovely restaurants, fish & chip shops, plenty of sand and calm water. You can go for a swim, skimboard or kayak.

One of the gems in the crown of cape town. Words can never describe this place. It has so many facets. The lovely old fishing village where coloured folk have lived for decades. The maniers wharf is stunning - best fish and chips in town. And I love the real restaurant too. The beaches are lovely. The views of the mountains are stunning. Then a meal and drive along Chapmans Peak - must be the prettiest place in the world.

A mix of travellers. Had a good cuple of hours at this mix of tourist attraction and working port. Saw plenty of seals, some being fed and seemingly quite tame. Entertained by the Jazz band, brought more curios, sawsnoek being laneded and auctioned and of course a cuppa and a cake

Scenic route; great places to eat!. Houtbay is a very scenic place. It sports a bird park, the largest in Southern Africa, the fishing harbour and numerous other facilities. Mariners Wharf restaurant and take-away is a must-see and frequented by both locals and foreigners.

A must stop one a Peninsula Tour. Hout Bay boasts some of Cape Town's best seafood restaurants who source and serve the freshest seafood you will ever taste. The calamari (squid) is a definite must! It is the most tender and tastiest calamari out there!
Seal Island. On a visit I recommend you take a boat trip to seal island. There are hundreds of seals, and if you are lucky you may see the whales

Touristy at one end and functional at the other. Hout Bay has the very touristy Mariners Wharf and a long pier at one end, along with a few shops and several boating berths, offering tourists trips out to Seal Island. At the far end of the bay it seemed much more functional, with fishing boats aplenty and a more industrial feel. The Bay is beautiful – even on a bad day when the mist was hanging low, I got some nice views of the steep hills around the bay, although I do feel that I missed out, as the clouds were very low when I visited.  Snoukies Fish and Chips is real highlight and is worth a trip to the far end of the bay - this place is a real gem - the best fish and chips! Hout Bay is a nice destination just a short trip out of Cape Town.

Great area and photos. This area is really beautiful from all angles. The seals that come ashore seem pretty used to humans, as they come right up to you. The views of the mountain and the water are also great. I would like to spend more time here the next time I'm in Cape Town!

perfect bay. a beautiful small town close to CapeTown with a beautiful old working harbor and great sea food restaurants and a fantastic view over the whole bay up to Chapman`s Peak, great to get away from the noisy city for a day, nice little shops, but be aware of thiefs

Unforgetable. We made a quick stop here on a rainy day. It was still amazing. We saw seals swimming in the harbor, loads of great fishing boats, and had a great stroll along the water. There are some nice antique shops and places for a peaceful drink while watching the bay. It was worth the stop.

Quite little town. The town is not very big, and cramped inbetween the mountains. it is great for just walking tru, and spending some time on the beach. with little luck you will see a lot of seals while walking over the quay.
Beautiful,tranquil.. Hout bay is always an especially good place to visit. The view,the wonderful fresh seafood,the diversity of the people. What more can I say??
Best place to buy carved souvenirs.. Vendors along the beach sold amazing stone animal carvings from Tanzania. Priced very reasonably. I had to keep in mind suitcase weight and size!!

Hout bay Fun. I loved the entire atmosphere and the trips were full of great sites. I will definitely go on a more regular basis. We took a group of family members and it was enjoyed all around. The shops are quite interesting and we bought beautiful amenities for our family outing. The little fish and chips shops everywhere is amazing and really gives you that South African feeling. There was also a bunch of people catching fish that where basically just washing up on the shore in bundles. What an amazing experience.

Loads to do - great day out. Bay Market every weekend starting at 5pm on a Friday including evenings is pretty buzzy, lovely beach to walk along, great fish and chips in a box at the wharf, original shops, great walking up on the mountains or along cliff paths, beautiful views, Sunday craft market, Chapman's Peak drive..... so much in such a small area.

Best of both worlds. In Hout Bay you get the best of both worlds. You have the beautiful beach in front of you and the mountain along side it. Stunning views. Also to for really fresh seafood - calamari, hake, snoek etc you have to visit Hout Bay. Definitely worth a visit. When I'm in Cape Town I make sure I go because the seafood it so fresh and good.

Unique. A unique area where nature, markets, etc meet - the most delicious fish can be enjoyed at Snoekies - seals playing in the water, birds screaming for their inch of hte catch of the day - sometimes smelly, but worthwhile visiting - a wonderful experience!
Lunch and then??. I never know what to do once you've had lunch and walked along the beach… nice for a couple of hours but you couldn't spend the day there.

This is a must see, must do!. The big red hop-on hop-off tour bus stops at the entrance to Hout Bay. Even if you just walk around and see surfers, seals, boats, and the outdoor and indoor craft market, it's worth the visit. You can always catch the next bus 35 minutes later. If you have time, though, take the short boat ride from Hout Bay to Duiker Island and see playful (albeit lazy) seals climbing all over each other.

Fantastic view, Fantastic food!. The view was breathtaking, whether you are walking down the rows of boats or walking along the beach.The seafood platter was extremely tasty at an affordable price. Best thing? It came piping hot!! The sign was right, it was indeed the best seafood served there!
Hout Bay. Its a peaceful and beautiful part of Cape Town.You can hop on a boatt and visit Seal Island.

Charming Atmosphere. Where the old and the new meet.... Hustle and bustle of people from all over the world mingled with the local coloured people with an unuque character of their own. The majestic mountains and Chapman's Peak drive with the unequalled beauty of the ocean far below, with whales in season and awesome sunsets. Wonderful accommodation and restaurants
Beautiful bay. Stopped on our way to Seal island cruise. Locals selling numerous crafts on the docks.
total colourful africa. beautiful and friendly with really cheap markets and you can go to seal island from here. I loved it

Love it!. Hout bay is a little fishing village with a very interesting history and quirky personality. The beach is cute, but the main attraction for me is the market! They have a huge variety of goods for sale and a lot of it is very unique and interesting, which I love! Before you go I would recommend reading a quick history online because it really is such a fascinating little place! The food in general is very good,from fresh fish and chips served the "traditional" way to more upmarket foodie restaurants, I have never been disappointed at any of the restaurants. The only thing is parking can be a bit scarce during peak times and of course the water is freezing.
Lovely seaside town with a great beach. Quite large harbour home to a fishing flleet and tourist boats travelling to and from a busy seal colony. Good Restaurants and lovely quiet beach.

A fishing village enroute to the Cape. Hout Bay is a working fishing village which is unpretentious and can be quite busy.The beach is quite nice but as with all SA beaches - very cold!! Obviously it gets pretty windy here as there is sand everywhere, on every street, in every corner.Fish and Chips at the Mariners Wharf are a must - and they really live up to their reputation. It was cold on the day we visited, so we had lunch in the restaurant upstairs and the food was truly superb. It was quite a surprise as we were expecting the usual tourist standard fare. It was really the best fish and chips I have ever had (and with teenage kids tagging round with us, we have tried a lot!)It's worth a walk along the marina to see the fishing trawlers and lobster boats. There are seals everywhere and plenty of locals touting for cash to buy fish for them. The local market was interesting, and there are plenty of options if you want to go for a boat ride to see seals.For surfers, the point at Hout Vay is also know as Dungeons and this surf spot can pull a decent 40-50 foot wave when its working. Its a pretty impressice sight.Definitely worth a visit, HOut Bay is a good place to stop for lunch on your way to the Cape.

Ok Place To Refresh Towards Cape Point. This is a wide open bay that has some great views from the road on the way to the Cape.The pier has some eating options and bathroom facilities. There are many touts selling souvenirs you have seen in every day or your travels through South Africa. There are some bars and restaurants just off the pier. This is a good pit stop on your way to the Cape.
The peer leaves a lot to be desired.. This was not anything to write home about. The peer is overrun and the restaurants are not good.

Check out the market. We enjoyed a visit to the Hout Bay market. The goods in the market are considerably more expensive than Green Market square, but they are also better quality and more modern types of things. The food in the market is exceptional - try the wood fired pizza!
The Republic of hout Bay. Known as the republic by locals as is is set on the other side of the mountains in a quaint fishing village. Great restaurants and views, and a must see when in the cape.

Dunes the place to eat!. We stopped in here after driving down Chapman's peak and had a late lunch and wine at Dunes on the front of the beach.Food was amazing and we had a great view of the bay.Highly recommend.
Not what it used to be. This used to be a very picturesque village, but not any more. It is still worth getting a boat to Seal island from the port, but avoid the company Drumbeat charter....

Magnificient Bay. Hout Bay has a fishermen wharf which is mst less touristic than the famous waterfront in Cape Town.The road around the bay is one of the most impressive ocean road you can imagine. Take care when driving there!!
Seal Island. took a ferry to the seal colony and that was just a WOW moment as well, it was an out of body experience, i am truly happy with My Tours guide, i learned a lot...

Great place for lunch. While driving to the Cape of Good Hope we stopped at a beautiful little bay for lunch. We ate on the deck at the Mariners Wharf and enjoyed the action on the street and beach around the bay. It is a beautiful little place and we also watched a native feeding the seals fish from his mouth!
Seal Island. Make sure whe you go to Hout Bay that you go on the Seal Island tour, its amazing watching all the seals
Great day out. Fabulous lunch on the quayside. Whatched the seals begging for fish scraps. Great fun.

Nice place for lunch and having fun. Hout Bay is popular fishing village after Camps Bay and Landudno Village.You can find lovely restaurants where you can have fresh fish caught the same day.There are also some popular places for fish and chips.If you want to prepare your lunch at home, wait for the fisherman to come with their boats and choose from the best fresh fish in SA. It is also totally cheap. This is the most popular fish market I know here around Cape Town. In Hout Bay there is a big Craft Market where you can find nice hand made souvenirs and also have lunch ,or cake and drink. It's very nice to visit this place with your friends when you have time. Try to feed the birds near the sea, it's also a nice experience because they are waiting for that :)

A liitle semi-independent republic on the outskirts of cape town. fish on the rocks at snoekies, paddle in the water and soak up some sun. and the awesome drive over chapman's peak to get there from CT
This photo they shown is NOT Hout Bay. Some nice boutique shops but nothing special. On a bad day catch the smell from the fish factories
Residential area. quiet, sleepy town. Nice views and an example of paradox in South Africa. Wealthy homes alongside delapidated squatter camp! worth a visit, bus or car
Shopping and Fishing. Twas good to experience a bit of the fish market in hout bay

One of South Africa's best attractions. Hout Bay have been for a long time one of my favorite attractions, the beautiful mountains and at its foot the ocean, the little village have a paradise feel. But of recent years crime have spoiled this beauty. The new shopping areas looks good and there is an great new Woolworths, and curio shops. The harbor remains an great attraction and the sea food is some of the best in Africa , especially if it is tuna season, sushi will be as fresh as it can come.

Loved Hout Bay. Hout Bay is a sweeping stretch of sand in a mountaineous coastline setting. However dogs roam on beacj and owners do not pickup so I would not come here for a beach day. Nice harbour and shops/restaurants with bonus of Sea Lions in water.
Worth a visit.

Meet-up with the Cape Fur Seals in Hout Bay. Hout Bay (Wood Bay in English) is located outside Cape Town. A boat ride provides an oppurtunity to see the colony of Brown Fur Seals/Cape Fur Seals in Hout Bay.
Pretty beach!. This beach has a lovely view and is great for a walk or a horse ride. Its generally protected from the wind and the water is warmer than further up the west coast.
Very Pretty!. A really nice place to stop (and take-in the Harbour Views) for a light lunch/early evening snack but not much more to do.........................

A great little village. Hout Bay has it all - nice walking beach, good restaurants, interesting shops, and a few places of interest. My favorite spots in Hout Bay are: The weekend market at the harbor, Spiro's (Greek Restaurant), Chapman's Peak hotel for calamari, World of Birds, Dunes for sundown, and Chapman's Peak drive for a walk and ridiculously beautiful views.

Seafood. Food and great seafood is what comes to mind when i thinbk of Hout Bay.
Village with a diffrence.

A little piece of Paradise. To know Hout Bay is to love it - its idiosyncracies, local characters, great seafood, stunning scenery and outdoor activities. Beach isn't the best you'll find, and the working harbour often leaves a lingering smell in the air, but it's a hidden piece of paradise away from the bustle of downtown Cape Town. Worth the adventure!

Hout Bay horizons. Hout Bay is surrounded by stunning mountain scenery and is a departure point for many amazing drives. Especially good is the drive around Chapman's peak.
For goodness sake, use a picture of Hout Bay and not Clifton Beach on this site!
Classic old style harbour. Sand, boats, seals, shopping and cafe's. The sand when it is windy blows onto the road. Cool!
Fish & Chips. If you want a good lunch, then here's the place to go. I have never been disappointed in Hout Bay, the best fish & Chips can be bought here - Snoekies

Little Gem!. Hout bay is a little villiage on the outskirts of a big city. Its very eco friendly, very relaxed, with lots of great restaurants and bars. We come for an extended holiday every year, and love the fact that people remember us, and always greet us with a smile.
loads of fun things going on - never a dull moment!!
contrasts. well if you like contrasts you might differ from my opinion. One side are expensive houses and on the oppsite side you find squatter camps?
Nice to walk the dog. Hout Bay beach is definitely a perfect spot for walking you animals. Would not swim there though. The fish and chips in this are is good to.

fantastic bay. lucky to stay 6 nights in a friend's house high up on the hill with spectacular unforgettable views pool and superb house.The weekend market is fun ....crowded interesting and a super idea to feast on various snacks and wines. We went for coffee and breakfast the nest day and hope it continues. Lots of souvenir shops in front of the harbour.White sand but windy and the ocean freezing to us! Lovekly to stroll along the longish bay.Had agood Greek meal here.Could easily stay for a week.Water

Beautiful. Spectacular views of a famous fishing village - a must for any tourist! A view good seafood restuarants, a lovely beach and some fantatsic boat trips to Seal Island and a Ship Wreck! Take a drive over Chapmans Peak, a spectacular road along the coast and thru some mpountains!
Fish and Ships. Lovely little area with craft shops and Pietie the seal which gets fed regularly. It also has the most amazing snoek.

A Little Piece of heaven Fell From The Sky. ......and it was called Hout Bay.A truly authentic old world fishing bay where you can go to simply soak up the athmosphere or in search of fish so fresh it will melt in your mouth when cooked.It really is a lovely way to spend an afternoon or morning. The fresh sea air will relax you and the views and sights will stimulate your senses. And this is only one of the myriad of things to do in beautiful South Africa. You will not be disappointed......
Beautiful Bay. Really is a spectacular bay! And stunning beach with great restaurants, worth a day trip and a visit.
nice. one off those places to visit - the Hout Bay market is great fun and good food

Simply great!. Hout Bay is simply my favourite part of Cape Town. It has a chilled, relaxed atmosphere and has everything you might want! Harbour, amazing restaurants, breath taking views. A must see on any visit to Cape Town!
A Childhood favourite. The best fish and chips in Cape Town. Had our best holiday as kids almost 35 years ago

cute bay with quaint shops, fresh fish and beautiful views. (The Republic of) Hout Bay is resplendent with quaint shops, fresh fish and beautiful views of the 12 Apostles mountain range and Chaplains peak.You can also catch a ferry from here to Seal Island.The price for this seal island trip is a third of what we paid for the same kind of this in Mossel bay, so it seems like value for money.Other than sea food and pearl shopping, and soaking in the views, theres not too much to do here as the water is too cold to swim.
nice fisherman place. lovely harbour and fun seal island trips. don't do world of birds though it dirty and sad
The harbour!. Hout Bay's harbour is a must see and go enjoy the best fish and chips in Cape Town at Mariner's Wharf!

Gorgeous Hout bay beaches and mountains. I visited Hout bay last month, My family and I stayed in Hout Bay. From the minute we got to Hout Bay we loved every moment with the stunning mountains and beaches. Mariners wharf was very nice with a couple of boats that did tours to 'seal island' and 'chapmans peak'. I especially loved the 'chapmans peak toll route' between Noordhoek and Hout Bay. You get the most awesome views. Also Hout Bay had gorgeous beaches with lovely sand dunes to explore. It was a lovely place to unwind and to get away from the city.
Seals. Lovely bay - famous for fish and chips! Smells real nice! Worth a visit!

Hout Bay is delightful. Hout Bay is a former fishing village that has become a sought-after residential location in Cape Town. The beach is not as beautiful as some of the other beaches in Cape Town, but the bay itself is stunning, and from most places in Hout Bay the views are spectacular. There are many restaurants and bars, but it's not as touristy as Camps Bay. Chapmans Peak drive, overlooking Hout Bay, is probably one of the most scenic drives in the world. Hout bay has loads of character, being famous for its fish and chips, and more recently the vibrant new harbour market.
Over-rated. Normal tourist clap, some nice restaurants, but they could have done more with the area. Hout Bay harbour is average and dead, nothing like kalk Bay harbor which buzzes. Seen once, done
Views to die for. Lovely area for a day trip. Good spot for lunches and boat trips to seal island great.
Lovely Bay. A drive over Constantia Neck or along Chapman's Peak drive ends in Hout Bay. Loads of terrific restauants and fisherman's harbour.

Best fish and chips in Cape Town. Like: The concept of this quaint fishing village; the harbour is still a working harbour and it is common to see fishermen bring their supplies off their boats and sometimes sell to the public. Mariner's Wharf at the harbour offers the best snoek, calamari and chips in Cape Town! Beautiful inland or coastal drive to get to Hout Bay.Dislike: Hout Bay can get incredibly busy during peak periods and school holidays. can also get sometimes very windy.
Only went for fish and chips!. We only went to Hout Bay for fish and chips. The bay itself is pretty - although the area is not as well kept as Camps Bay for example.

Inspiring and beautiful!. This was one of the sites that made me really feel like I was far from home and visiting someplace that was a unique and different place in the world. It is stunningly beautiful and on a clear day the photography opportunities are wonderful. A must visit natural site in So. Africa!

Nice place where to stay. I stayed at a friend's house for a few days and I have to say it's worth at least spending here a few hours. It's a quiet and beautiful bay and when alone I spent the day at the beach and just strolling around. Very relaxing. At the harbour you can see the fishing boats coming back and have some excellent fish and chips.
Lovely. A lovely place to visit,great bars & restaurants & scenery to die for.

Look for the Whales. This is a stunning location with whale spotters along the roadside looking out over the bay. Be careful of wind gusts when standing near the edges to take pictures and be sure to stop in one of the nearby townships and also the waterfront.

Experience the harbour.. Hout Bay Harbour is where you will mingle with all the local fishermen, the local kids swimming and the locals cramming the restaurants over week-ends. The vibe is interesting, the beach is wide and long, cruises can be enjoyed from this point and you can eat with great sea views. It's a multi-cultural town and the craft market on Sundays offers mainly African crafts. The swimming is safe, so it's great for families. There is not much else in Hout Bay but the beach and harbour (and World of Birds) are worth a visit.
Lovely Location. The bay is beautiful, ate at Mariner's Wharf. Great views when enjoying lunch!
Alright. Not as scenic as I thought it would be but a good Sunday market

Beautiful Hout Bay, Cape Town, South Africa. Hout Bay is a nice coastal town a bit north of Cape Town. Really beautiful coastline, cliffs, sea... but all white, with a Black township where workers live in appalling conditions on the outskirts. Although almost 2 decades after Nelson Mandela was freed and democratic elections held, the segregation by race and class pervades the South African culture, and destroys (for me) the natural beauty of the coast. The harbour is nice, fish and chips restaurant tasty, with seals/sea lions playing along the docks. It is a nice place to visit, but I just couldn't get past the segregated lives separating rich/poor and Black/white communities. To get there, most whites rent a car and drive from Cape Town. Most Blacks and Brown families take a bus from the central bus station by the Grand Parade downtown Cape Town. The bus goes along the coast, passing very pretty coastline and beach communities, again, exclusively white. Once in Hout Bay, there is a Brown township up the hill overlooking the town, separate from the Black township. You should check out all three areas and see for yourself the "new South Africa."

An excellent seaside community near Cape Town. We loved Hout Bay so much that we went twice during our recent trip to Cape Town. The Seal Island ferry boat trip was nice and not expensive. The white sandy beaches were also great, although the water was too cold for swimming. We also liked strolling around a bit around the marina area. The most enjoyable part of our stop was simply eating fresh calamari at the kiosk stands, picnic style on the little wooden tables. This was just great, making a highly memorable stop in Hout Bay. Hout Bay can be best visited by CitySightSeeing Bus Tour (Blue Line) or as part of a Cape Peninsula day trip, where you'll probably stop here for 45 minutes to 1 hour to see the seals. Either way, Hout Bay is a very enjoyable place to spend an hour or more.We definitely recommend finding a way to fit Hout Bay into your Cape Town trip.

Seacliffe Lodge at Hout Bay is the best base for Cape Town area. We spent a week at Hout Bay and loved it. Like the other reviewers, we felt safe and walked to the mall, Spar and the Wharf. The restaurants were some of the best we've been to. The view of Hout Bay is spectacular. It's just too bad Chapman's Peak drive isn't open. Hout Bay is very accessable by car, taxi or the hop on hop off bus. Seacliffe Lodge looks on to the wharf and is the best central location. The service we received from the owners was second to none.

The Best In Self Catering 6 In The Circle Hout Bay. Two lovely self - catering apartments in a beautiful setting within the suburbs of Hout Bay; ideally situated for exploring the delights of the Western Cape.The apartments are well equipped and very comfortable.The garden pool is a delight , a boon for weary travellers.Nikki and Paul are considerate and generous hosts. We are seasoned travellersand have had no hesitation in putting this gem of a venue high on our 'wish list' of places to return to. Jacqui and John Norfolk England February 2009.

Best place to stay in Cape Town. Myself and a friend recently stayed in Hout Bay for ten days and we think we made a brilliant choice. For starters the natural surroundings are spectacular with the beautiful moutains and sea. The beach was a lovely place to be especially during the evenings when everybody seemed to be having a great time. There are numerous restaurants and cafes to eat in nearly all with a great view of the bay, you will be spoilt for choice. We felt very safe there and had no problem walking around on our own, even in the evenings. It's a great place to stay if you are a keen photographer as you will get great sunset shots especially from the Chapman's Peak side of the bay, but the views are great anytime and anywhere. The seal island cruise is definately worth doing, you will see thousands. We will definately go back, it's a very special place.
